name: Portal 2
description: The "Perpetual Testing Initiative" has been expanded to allow you to design co-op puzzles for you and your friends!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 / Vista / XP Processor: 3.0 GHz P4, Dual Core 2.0 (or higher) or AMD64X2 (or higher) Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Video card must be 128 MB or more and with support for Pixel Shader 2.0b (ATI Radeon X800 or higher / NVIDIA GeForce 7600 or higher / Intel HD Graphics 2000 or higher). DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 8 GB available space Sound Card: DirectX 9.0c compatible

reviews.review_text: The best game ever made by Valve. Great story, beautiful dialogues with funny jokes, interesting puzzles, perfect atmosphere and a lot of fun in co-op with friends. You made a great work, Valve, and thank You for this absolute masterpiece. 10/10.

Portal was sort of a little experiment of a huge company. That’s why success of the first part of the Portal was a surprise even for the VALVe. Therefore seriously question arose about the Portal 2. And what we got? Let's see.  　STILL ALIVE?  　　The game begins with the fact that Chell along with her new partner, personality module Wheatley, is trying to escape from an abandoned Aperture Science laboratory. Throughout the game, the plot makes a interesting twists. Individual deserves compliments perfect finale, after which there remain only a warm feeling. In Portal 2 no epic stories, huge explosions, incredible action, or the salvation of humanity. Instead, there is a charismatic characters, intelligent humor and interesting puzzles.  　ONE IS GOOD, BUT TWO IS BETTER  　　One of the achievements of the new Portal has been the emergence of the cooperative. Co-op story is a continuation of the plot of the single player. At first I thought that the only difference of the cooperative is the presence of two players with portal-guns, instead of one. In fact, the cooperative has unique ideas. Many puzzles solving quite differently. I advise you not to play cooperative with a random person (there is that possibility), and play it with a good friend.  　ENDLESS TESTS  　　In game was added a level editor, so anyone can create their own test chambers or try to play the levels of other players. To be honest, most of the player-created levels are too simple or ridiculous. But there is sufficient interesting maps (and some of them really hard). In no case do not miss the community maps.  　Multiplayer: 　　Online: Θ Θ Θ Θ Θ Θ Θ Θ Θ Θ  　　Co-op: ☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺O 　Storyline: ☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺O 　Graphics: ☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺O 　Gameplay: ☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺  　  　Complexity of the achievements: All achievements can be easily earned (if you have good friend for the co-op) in the one-two walkthrough.  　　　　 VALVe made another good 　　game. With good intelligent humor, 　　charismatic characters and unusual 　　interesting gameplay.  　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　As expected, nine out of ten [9/10].

Very Impressive. Because this message is pre-recorded, any comments we may make about your success are speculation on our part. Please disregard any undeserved compliments. – GLaDOS  There is so much to be impressed about in Portal 2. From the amazingly developed and memorable characters to the brilliantly balanced puzzles, Portal 2 may well be the best puzzle game ever created.  I purchased Portal 2 about 11 months after it was released. I didn’t even know who Valve was back then, I didn’t know what Source was and I didn’t have a clue about anything to do with the Portal story, but after playing it, Valve quickly became my favourite game developers. Back then, I was only interested in 2 things. Gameplay, and graphics. We had only recently upgraded to an Xbox 360 from a very old, original PlayStation, so the games I’d bought for the Xbox were, as you can imagine, amazing, but Portal 2 had better graphics than any other game I’d been playing. I was also interested in the gameplay, and Portal 2 nailed it with its hilarious characters and difficult puzzles. As I grew up and played the game over and over again, I noticed things I hadn’t noticed before, like secret rooms and signs on the walls, which got me into researching the story. Trust me, the story is deep… but, this review is spoiler free, so I’d encourage you to do it yourself!  Portal 2 is a brilliant combination of puzzles, well developed characters, and an RPG element, which makes the game amazing, and better than any other puzzle game I’ve played before. To start off with, you wake up in a strange room, and you meet a funny little “ball” robot named Wheatly. He guides you over to the old testing tracks, but on your way to escape the facility, he accidently turns on the main core robot, who controls everything, GLaDOS! She “forgives” you (play the oringinal portal) and instead of killing you, she spares your life and instead makes you test, as she indicates “for the rest of your life”. I’m not going to say any more, because it would be a shame to spoil it for anyone, but I highly recommend you play this game. This is one of the few games I would say to buy at full price if you have enough, because it’s totally worth it. There is also a co-op campaign that has a completely different story, it's great to play with a friend. Thanks for reading!

The original Portal was a success I don't think anyone anticipated. Arguably the best part of The Orange Box, it was a remarkably clever and original puzzle game, with an absurd amount of character. But to everyone's disappointment, it was all over too soon. But we were not forsaken; quite the contrary. With Portal 2, a direct sequel (by which I mean to say you should play the original first, as well as before reading this review which will inevitably spoil it), Valve has not only given us a bigger and better game, but one of the greatest pieces of interactive entertainment ever. I mean no hyperbole when I say Portal 2 is an absolute masterpiece on a grand scale, and a game absolutely everyone should get the chance to play!  Fair warning, there is no way to talk about Portal 2 without spoiling everything that occurs in the first game, so keep that in mind if you have yet to play it (by which I have to ask, why the heck not?). Disclaimers out of the way, Portal 2 once again places you inside Aperture Science, an expansive underground scientific research and testing facility with fewer ethics than living test subjects. Which is to say just you, Chell, reimprisoned and put to sleep for who knows how long, only awakened when the entire facility is on the verge absolute destruction. Unlike before however you aren't alone, now joined by a naive little robot named Wheatly. With GLaDOS in pieces, escape seems like a simple objective. That is until someone flips a switch to turn her back on...  The original Portal is still one of the best written, and most hilarious games I've played, and yet its sequel is miles ahead of it in every possible way. With only a handful of characters, it's amazing how charming and witty every line is. Hilarious, clever, and maybe even a little touching, I can't think of a game that even comes close to matching how perfectly timed and expertly written every moment of Portal 2 is. It's minimal cast does an amazing job of breathing life into the decrepit facility, and makes the simple aspect of walking from one door to the next and immensely enjoyable activity.   And it isn't just the writing that deserves remark, but how Valve has implemented it to seamlessly interact with your actions. Characters respond to what you're doing in such a realistic manner that it's hard to believe they are simply programs setup to do so. With so many games relying on traditional, uninteresting storytelling mechanics, Portal 2 moves the medium forward in ways developers need to take note of.  However smartly written the dialog may be, it's in the portal puzzles themselves that Valve's intelligence really shines. Not content to simply reiterate the same mechanic we saw in the first game, new elements such as propulsion gel and laser maneuvering cubes are added regularly and consistently expand on the basic portal mechanic in unexpected and interesting ways. Every time I thought I'd seen all the ways a mechanic could be used, Valve expanded the spectrum and again astounded my expectations with the outwardly simple variances in usage that never would have occurred to me. Even on my second playthrough the puzzles never stopped being incredibly rewarding to solve, and giving me just enough of a challenge to consistently test my intellect in a wholly unique fashion.  For how old the Source engine is at this point, you'd never know Portal 2 was built on it based on how it looks. To this day I am utterly astonished at what Valve manages to pull off with the engine, and this is easily its most impressive usage to date. The once sterile Aperture Science is now presented in a gorgeous display of disrepair. Walls crumbly around you, lights flicker and cast dazzlingly shadows, plants grow through into the facility, and it all looks absolutely amazing! Even with it's makeover, Aperture is still an eminently memorable and distinct place to inhabit, and the increased variety in locations does an impressive job of realizing the sheer size of the facility which we've only scratch the surface of.  I always forget to mention the soundtrack, not because it isn't a fantastic accompaniment to your journey through Aperture, but because it blends so well with the rest of the game that I almost forget it's there. That's not a slight against it however, it's a complement to how suited it is for the game that I can't separate one from another. It's a brilliant score with so many layers I couldn't begin to pick it apart to describe it to you (but thankfully I don't need to, as even if for some reason you don't play the game the soundtrack is freely downloadable). As for the ending, well let's just say Jonathan Coulton is a genius and leave it at that.  And then there is the coop mode; yet another brilliant way Valve has surprised me, turning the solitary campaign into a multiplayer experience that demands cooperation. This is what impresses me the most about the mode; it isn't just two players going through a game designed for one, but an entirely new set of levels purposely designed to force you to work with your partner to complete them. It's amazing what can be accomplished with two sets of portals, and this is fully taken advantage of in what are perhaps the best designed puzzles in the entire game. If you don't have a friend to play with, go make one for this game. It's something you shouldn't miss out on.  I can't get over it. I've been impressed by Valve numerous times in the past, love Portal to death, and thought I knew what I was getting with it's successor. But Portal 2 is so much more than that. It's an incredible achievement in everything it attempts, from it's outstanding script to the bewildering puzzles and spectacular presentation. It's the best game Valve has ever made, one of my all time favorites, and without a doubt one of the medium's greatest accomplishments!  Now if you'll excuse me, there's testing to do.   You can read more of my writing on  Kritiqal  [kritiqal.com] .

Portal 2 is the amazingly imersive and fun sequel to the amazingly imersive and fun videogame known as portal. It isn't however one of those sequels where they give you the same product with prettier graphics and do nothing to improve on it; the game contains many great new innovations. At its core, portal is a puzzle platformer game, and this aspect is combined with the story in a way that forces you to think of outside-the-box solutions. The characters are all compelling; even the silent protagonist gets some characterization during the game. She's smart, good at jumping, and is able to jump over both emotional and physical obstacles with ease. When things get tough, and she has a murderous AI tryng to kill her at every turn, she just keeps testing. The game has essentially three modes. There's the story, co-op, and community made maps. The community for this game is amazing. They take all the resources Valve has lent them, and they make games barely recognizable as part of portal. It could also go in the opposite direction, and you get a game that feels like it should be a part of the main story. One major downside is that you cann't play co-op, or in community maps, if you lack an internet connection. There are many great maps that make you think and analyze the tools you're given in different ways; It's a shame that you can't just download and play one of them while on the go.  If you're not into puzzle platforming, in-depth and imersive storytelling doesn't impress you, and you don't like any of your friends enough to play this with them without committing murder, this isn't the game for you. 10/10

Portal 2 is a truely unique puzzle action game which makes great use of a portal gun that can form two seperate portals which would allow the player to traverse the levels.  A great sequel to the original Portal game, Portal 2 is a much longer game which features much more complex puzzles and introduces lovable new characters. The voice acting and dialogue in this game is amazingly entertaining and funny, I found myself chuckling multiple time during the game due to the character dialogues! The level design in this game is also great as there were some levels which left me stumped for quite awhile and it took me quite alot of brain power to solve them and that gave me a great feeling after doing so!  This game features a co-operative mode which allows players to play with people in your friend list or complete strangers through match-making. There are some form of customization options such as hats in the co-operative mode that can be unlocked through completing the game. There was supposed to be more customization options available in a shop but it has since been discontinued. Trading is also unavailable which is pretty unfortunate as it would be great for players to exchange or sell cosmetics.  There is also a level creation tool in this game which allow players to create their own Portal 2 levels and share it online with others by uploading it to the workshop! Several interesting extra content includes a portal 2 comic which serves as a prequel to the game and a super 8 (a pretty old movie by now) interactive game demo.  Overall, Portal 2 is a very entertaining game with great puzzles, characters and voice acting. I would give it a 9/10! A must buy if you enjoy action puzzle games!
Great voice acting, challenging and fun gameplay,amazing co-op and a great pace make this one of the best puzzle games I've ever played.  10/10

Game of the year, and screw you if you think otherwise. Both the single player and co-op games have exceeded all my expectations. The single player story reaches up to 8 hours of play this time around, offering jaw dropping environments and a LOT more complex portal puzzles with a dozen new elements sure to put even the most clever of players through their paces. The brilliant writing is back, piecing together the mystery behind Aperture Labs through observing the scenery and of course, enjoying the extremely hilarious lines brought about by pre-recorded PA messages before the disaster, and the dialogue from the few main characters. Finally, the co-op mode makes full, clever use of both players that's sure to keep you and your friend glued to the game for extended periods of time. Aside from little replay value, I can't think of a single complaint beyond that. This is the most fun you will have with a game for a long time.

Let me start off by saying I don't like playing puzzle games. I'm not great at them to begin with, and they frustrate me sometimes.  Portal pretty much changed my outlook on that. I'd known about the Portal games for quite a long time before actually playing them. The first game was a great start, but I did wish there could have been more substance.  Portal 2 is the embodiment of the perfect sequel. The gameplay improves greatly from the first; the chambers feature more factors, like the gels, hard light bridges, etc., and feel much more challenging. And, if you somehow get bored of the main Portal 2 campaign, there's also co-op!  Storyline-wise, it exceeded my already high expectations. The dialogue was usually witty (GLaDOS), hilarious (Wheatley), or both. While there were very few characters in this game, it did a good job of making them complex and interesting. Of course, there are still some loose ends in the plot that were purposely left out, but I feel like it was better off being vague.  Portal 2 definitely lives up to its reputation. After all, it takes a lot to be featured in hundreds of easter eggs across the video gaming universe.

>plays co-op with sister >i do all thinking work and tell her where to put portals >GLaDOS tells us that im smart and did all the work and that my sister didn't do anything  10/10 would laugh at my sister getting roasted by GLaDOS again  But seriously now:  OMFG I DON'T EVEN KNOW HOW I SHOULD WRITE THIS ------------------------------------------------------------------ Most games bore me, frankly. But this game, a very repetitive game where you just use portals over portals, kept me addicted the whole way through. This probably is the second Steam game I was interested in enough to beat. Some areas were a bit harder to solve (probably because my brain can't function well at 4am), so I just went to bed, and the next day I'd try again, and beat it. -Quick Review-   Portal2 is a first person puzzle game developed by Valve and released 2011. This game was greatly anticipated when it was announced and we all waited in anticipation for the release. The game was not a disappointment, the developers brought us back to Aperture Laboratories and put us to work on new and innovative puzzles, Portal1 and 2 will always be one of my most favorite puzzle games, period.     -Detailed breakdown review-    Story:    You wake up in a strange hotel-looking room, after awakening you discover you're actually still inside Aperture Laboratories and the whole place is falling apart! You need to find a way out and escape before the whole lab falls down around your ears!     Gameplay:  The whole game is based on the core concepts of two portals  (an Orange/red and Blue Portal) , be it moving objects through these portals, moving yourself between these portals, or jumping off high objects to reach hard to reach places, the game is a brainteaser in such a wonderful way. As the catchphrase goes “prepare to think with portals”. There are a number of features in Portal2, there are Single player, Co-op, Community Test Chambers/Workshop, Steam Achievements, and challenge modes where you can compete against your friends for fastest times, least portals used, steps, and more.    Achievements:  There are 51 Achievements for Portal2, Most of the single player achievements are straightforward fun and challenging to get... There are also Co-op achievements, so it would be best to make or get a friend to help you out.   Price:  Portal2 is priced at $19.99 that will be the best 20 dollars you spend. But if you're on a tight budget like me you might want to wait for a 75% off sale, since the game was released in 2011 there's a very good chance that there will be sale for it.   Conclusion:  I really can't sum up how great Portal2 is without saying “look, if you're even remotely interested in trying it out, you don't grasp just what an outstanding puzzle game it is. I highly recommend Portal2 to everyone and anyone.  ------Edits and updates------ Edit/Update September 13, 2015: Here's the URL to see my review for   Portal

An awesome, must have, action puzzler. With memorable characters and a great atmosphere, Portal 2 combines a great humorous narrative with excellent gameplay. It also provides a lot of replayability with its excellent Multiplayer mode as well as new levels via the Workshop.

This game is my favorite of all time. It encompasses all that I enjoy about video games. Many other people like Portal, but I prefer Portal 2. While this game may not have the most impressive visuals, it more than makes up in a great story. From the well-written humor and sarcasm of Wheatley, to the lore behind Rat Man, this game has a beautifallly well-crafted narrative. The puzzle mechanics are great as well. However, I didn't enjoy the co-op mode quite as much as the singleplayer. Overall, I think this game is the best game of all time.  Pros -Excellent story & puzzle mechanics -Great atmosphere -Easy to run (I can run it on my $100 Dell laptop) -Best sequel -Great level editor -PS3 integration (No longer available) -Great price Cons -Multiplayer could have been improved -Visuals can be better (can be seen as a pro and a con)

This game, is incredible. The gameplay is nearly flawless, and the idea is brilliant. But first let me addresss everything the naysayers about this game say. 1: Predictable storyline. Hmmmmmmmmmmm I would agree with you there... except you didn't play the whole game. Seriously, almost everyone who says this has not played the whole game. And for the few who did, you clearly did not watch your surroundings enough. The point of the story was to make you want to play more, and it certainly did well on that note. 2: Not very hard. Again, play the whole game first. True, the game was not THAT hard, but I cannot think of a puzzle game that executes the gameplay as well as portal does. While the game itself was not terribly hard, the community has certainly made some head scratching test chambers that will make you want to eat your own words. 3: Crashes. The game does not crash anymore (except on windows 8 so far) so ignore those reviewers who say that because their review is now irrelevent.  Final score 9/10

Edit, wanted to rewrite this whole review. Portal 2 is the only reason I got back into gaming. I was at a school center, and I saw the place had a COMPUTER LAB, that also had PS3's and 360's. I was pretty happy. At the time, all I played was Minecraft. I used to play my Nintendo DS and DSi and my Gameboy, but I grew out of them. Usually the computers were taken by people playing Minecraft, so I sat myself down at a 360, and I checked under the counter for games. There it was. Portal 2. I played that game so much. Need for Speed: Most Wanted reeled me in to deciding that I wanted a PS3. I got a PS3 with Most Wanted and Portal 2 and other games. I was so happy. One day, I checked the inside and saw there was a code for a free copy on Steam. I remembered that I made a Steam a year ago because my friend told me to, but I never used it! I was happy because you needed a retail or Steam purchase to unlock all Steam features. I started to build my Steam collection from there, and I started an obsession over ALL Valve games, especially Counter Strike and Half Life. Portal 2 is sincerely my favorite game ever.

DQSwordz's Review on Portal 2  So Portal 2:  Portal 2 is a sequel to the game Portal. The game is about your character (Chell) being stuck in the Aperture Science Laboratories, you must find the famous gun named the Portal Gun. This isnt any old gun, this gun fires out orange and blue potarls these Portals transfer you to different places for example: if you fire a blue portal and fire a orange portal and walk through the blue portal, you will transport to the location of the orange portal. However, this game s not just about having fun with portals, Oh no, theres alot more to do. Your character has to do tests using the portal gun. These tests can be puzzling, but you will have to get through them! There is also a multiplayer option to this game, you and your friend can solve puzzles together, these puzzles can only be completed with your friend so you'll have to figure out what you have to do, and what your friend has to do. Depending on who is player 1 or 2 your characters are 2 different robots. Player 1 is the small robot named Atlas, and Player 2 is the tall robot named P-Body. Atlas has 2 differents shades of blue with his portal gun and P-Body has 2 different shades of orange with his portal gun. The singleplayer campaign is very fun (except for the puzzles that I mentioned earlier they can be frustrating but they can be fun also) the funniest part of the campaign is the voice actor for a small robot named Wheatly he has a really funny voice and says lots of funny things he is voice by Stephen Merchant. Anyway this game is very fun and exciting I would definately recommend it to all my friends and anyone else. 10/10 Because of... well baisically what I just said. This is a must buy! Thank you for reading my review. :) ~DQSwordz
This game is a brilliant follow up to its original. The story will keep amazing you and the puzzles are great. GET THIS GAME NOW!!.

GREAT GAME, had lots of fun playing it. Awesome physics and mechanics, great levels designs and gameplay. Didn't stay stuck for too long on any stage which made the game enven more enjoyable. Something that I really enjoy was the humor and the sarcasm in every scene (well done). There is only one down-side to the game: it is quite short (beated the co-op and single player in about 15h), but that is understandable, due to the fact that such great effort went to making every stage. I highly recommand this game, more specifically to people who love platformers and strategy game. I don't regret anything about this purchase, a couple of nights (even days) of fun. Once again, GREAT GAME.

Let me start by saying I'm quite a fan of the Portal series. The gameplay ideas are well thought out and the aesthetics of an old, worn down Aperture Science are stunning. The voice acting is amazing. Ellen Mclain's voice acting for GLaDOS is delightful, and Wheatley... oh, there's so many words to describe... The gameplay was very unique, you started out with a few levels from the first Portal game, before being thrown into a new set of tests, in a barren Aperture Sceince. When I got to the gel levels, I literally just sat there, saying to myself 'Wow... just, wow.' Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a fresh take on the Puzzle genre and for those who have time to kill.

One of the best games you'll ever play, I guarantee it.  Portal 2 has two great different game modes: Singleplayer and Co-Op. Sadly, if you don't have any friends, you won't be able to play the co-op, but in my opinion, the singleplayer alone would be worth your money.  Your problem solving skills will come to a test while playing this, but the story alone in this game is something to love; Portal 2 is a perfect example of great narration and character interaction with the player. The characters are enjoyable and the gameplay is easy enough to master. You can explore and find easter eggs that tell you more about the plot and the world you're in.  The co-op is also entertaining. Puzzles that you have to solve with a friend? Nothing could be more fun! The commands help communication alot - you can watch your friend in a small window to see what he sees, and with the easy commands you can tell your friend what to do. You practically don't need voice chat at all, but it does help alot! The puzzles in the game are fun as well, as the small storyline that goes along with the co-op - nothing major, but still enjoyable. And the community maps are endless - you can always get more community made maps, that can be wonderful to play through!  TL;DR: 10/10, would play again. Must buy game if on sale in Steam!  You can also have a drinking game with a friend, if one of you fails, take a shot. You'll get hammered in no time, because mistakes are bound to happen.

Main setting is same, you'll use portal gun trying to solve each arena... but this time, you'll have new helpful stuff like jump gel, speed gel and white gel at some point in game. Campaign is a lot longer because, you'll not just test the arenas... I would not spoil more, let's just say story is more complex than in first game. There're also co-op levels, where you and your friend will be tested in arenas which requires 4 portals to finish. It's very fun. And also, many user made maps... so you have tons of levels just for your pleasure.  10/10 - must have for Portal fans

What can I say that probably hasn't been said a hundred times already about this game.   The game play is unique and interesting, making you think outside the box at times and depending on your skill level with puzzle based games, possibly hit your head against that box a few times (but you know, in a good way). The writing is some of the most insulting dialog I've ever had the joy to sit through, laughing the whole way through. The detail and Easter eggs, which assist in telling you the story are scattered about, and add a fun exploration element that would have been completely non existent otherwise. The voice acting is perfect, the timing, the somewhat computeriness (it's a word now, deal with it), but still with so much emotional quality, admittedly mostly on the sarcastic variety, add to the interesting character far beyond the script alone. And finally the music, such an unusual mix, and songs that have become instant classics to which almost every gamer can now sing along to. All around everything I look for in an enjoyable, immersive, and captivating game play experience.  I have played both portal 1 and 2, and if I have any complaints at all about 2, and it's a small one, it's that I miss having more choices on where to place portals like you had in 1. I mean, I understand the reasoning behind it, give a person too many portable surfaces and you open up the puzzle to the point that it may become quite easy to skip the intended path, losing part of the challenge of the game. Still, this is the one thing that at times makes it hard for me to rate this game as better then the first, only because that element was something I found added to the fun of Portal in the first place. Being able to at times feel as though I had found my own solution to a puzzle, even if it was not how it was meant to be done. Also the simplicity of the first game added to the over all feel of a cold, sterile environment that really let the dialog and game mechanics take center stage.   That said, I found Portal 2 to be an excellent squeal that took a game that started an add in extra, like a prize in a box of cereal, and developed it into it's on beautiful work of art. I find myself replaying it, not to see if I can beat it faster, or get all the achievements (but huh, there's a thought), but more to smile again and enjoy the witty banter and get that warm fuzzy feeling of nostalgia from it all over again.  I haven't even tapped into the co op. To have such an awesome game as a single player probably would have in and of itself made portal 2 a successful sequel, but to add a completely separate, but included co op experience with all new levels, into the mix was more then I could have asked for. It allowed me to bring my dad into the game, which the single player had not managed on its own, and gave the community as a whole a canvas on which to build and share their own puzzles, thus allowing the fun to continue long after the end credits have rolled.   So what can I say about this game, quite a lot really, but seeing as how this is a review to presumably help that one person out there that hasn't quite decided if they should buy this game yet out, I'll simply say this. Buy it, you won't be sorry. It goes on sale enough these days that it's well worth the small amount you'd be spending to get such a full experience and fun story.

Except for The Bride of Frankensten (the 1935 film), there has never really been a sequel that was as good or better than that from which it spawned... until Portal 2. In fact, Portal 2 is twice the game that Portal was. So, I probably should love it more than Portal, but that will never happen.

If I were to recommend any single PC game to a friend, this would be it. This is the number one essential game to own if you are a PC gamer. Or any sort of gamer. Or any person at all, really.   This game has everything. From the gorgeous foliage-draped testing chambers of the Modern Aperature Laboratories to the goo-covered classic Aperature Science Innovators of the 1950s, there is always something amazing and new to look at.   And the puzzles... where do I begin? Portal 2 has all of the fun puzzles that you loved from the prequel, plus puzzles that include a myriad of new features that make you feel clever and stupid at the same time.  Portal 2 also introduces Wheatley, your rescuer from Aperature Labs and loyal companion (  sorry Companion Cube  ), and Cave Johnson, the founder of Aperature Science who you 'meet' through prerecorded messages that play throughout the levels. Both characters turn out to be deep,  smart , and hilarious. And, of course, there's GLaDOS, who never fails to disappoint with her compliments and motivational speeches.  In short, this game had me laughing and pulling my hair out at the same time, and I've never enjoyed myself more. The story itself was full of interesting twists and turns; I really never knew what was going to happen next. I mean, the ending made me sit with my jaw hanging open for what felt like 10 minutes. It alone was a cinematic masterpiece.  If you havent already picked up a copy of this game, I strongly urge you to. It is well worth the $20; you won't regret it.     14/10 would wait five more years for the next Portal again

Portal 2 is a game that combines a deviously planned and dark plot with great puzzles in the single player. It also has a great co-op option that has an entirely different and equally enticing campaign. I'll start with the single player.  ***NO SPOILERS FOLLOW***  Single Player:  In Portal 2s single player branch, the focus is mostly on the mysterious history of Aperture Science. Originally founded as a world reknown shower curtain company in the mid 1930's. When the 1940's came, they branched off to what they would continue to be, a company that broadened it's products to not just shower curtains, but all things science-related. They made the ground breaking development of the portal gun, or quantam tunneling device, which led them to begin mass-testing in which they created test chambers an used ens of thousands of 'privately kept' test subjects. Over the years though,they began to decay. All of this and so many more shady details are uncovereed in the single player.  Co-op/Multiplayer:  The multiplayer stars the two blue and orange robots you keep seeing in the trailers. One is you, one is your partner, and I would only play multiplayer with a close friend who you communicate well with, otherwise the tests may pose a frustrating ordeal. The great thing about this co-op though, is that it has its own story, and countless levels.  New Mechanics:  The main new mechanic is gels, which change a surface's properties, such as increasing speed while running on them or making them portalable. These are introduced midway through the campaign and are used from then on frequently.  Other:  EASTER EGGS. There are so many, and each adds to the mystery of an already unfathomably awesome campaign. If you finish everything else, these should give you another good few hours of gameplay.  Summary:  It's almost like reading a great novel, except you are the main character.  10/10  IF YOU DON'T BUY IT AND LOVE IT YOUR TOTALLY PSYCHOTIC.  I'm ready for a Portal 3!

Pros: Fast-paced and well-crafted story with twists, memorable characters explored and huge Aperture Science Facility, complete with backstory. Co-op is the best co-op I've played, genuinely collaborative, requiring synced actions at its hardest. Several new science tools to play around with, like light bridges, air funnels and gels(speed, jump and one for making surfaces portal-friendly). Co-op and SP have their own storyline and characters; they relate to one another, but without either spoiling the other. Level editor with leaderboards. Hilarious comedy, without losing drama and threat.  Cons: More characters and dialog mean less isolation and loneliness, which were part of the appeal of the first(all alone, with a psychotic AI, in a deadly facility).  My recommendation: Even if you don't think you're that good at puzzle games(I'm not), play this. The only people who shouldn't are those who don't like the dark comedy - watch a trailer to see if that aspect appeals to you or not.

What seemed like a highly successful experiment Portal 1 was, Valve decided to raise the bar once again by delivering a full fledged sequel. The highly anticipated game exceeded even the highest expectations I had and it's by far, the best game I ever played. While Portal 1 was more gameplay oriented, in this game you'll find that the storyline plays a more significant role. The cinematic effects, new gameplay techniques, excellent music, unpredictable plot twists and of course, GlaDOS's dark humor give Portal 2 a very special atmosphere, unlike in any other game I ever played. I'm not even talking about the amazing cooperative mode with free DLCs to come. An absolute must-have for sure.

The game is so new and inventive. The story is amazing and you can even find out more about it in their series of comics. The co-op is great and no improvements are needed, the only things that need improving are your friends. There is so much to this game that I don't want to spoil, so go and play it now!

Portal 2 is an interactive piece of art. It will be remembered in the future has one of the best games ever made by our generation not only for its great mechanics, great story with deep characters, great voice acting, great humor, great visual effects and great music but also for its entertainment and unlimited playability based on a solid and competent modding community.  On top of that, Portal 2 is also an exercise of flexibility to your mind.The game requires you to think against the laws of physics but, at the same time, you end to do it naturally. Physically speaking, everything that happens in this game is impossible and, at the same time, plausible.

So obviously, from the first game, you kill GLaDOS, and all of that happens. After you escape the building, you are somehow found by the labrotories and, of course, GLaDOS. You are put into a deep sleep, and like, three years later or something like that, you wake up in a dark dusty, dirty room, not like the one you went to sleep in. Then another character comes into the story. A core named Wheatley comes knocking on your door. You want to know who it is, so obviously, you open it. He comes in, talks for a bit, and then the room starts moving, smashing into walls, until you jump out. Then you are put into a whole lot of test chambers. I could beat most of them, some of them it took me a bit to figure them out. What I really didn't like was how Wheatley, my favorite character, turns into the bad guy. I've beaten the game, and my favorite chapter is 'The Part Where He Kills You', so sometimes, if I don't want to play from the beginning, I will play that chapter. So, my favorite part of that chapter is when I'm in his lair. I know what to do, how to do it, but I think it's cool when I shoot a portal to the moon, and everything gets sucked in. It really stands out to me when GLaDOS deletes Caroline, and her voice changes, I don't like how she gets rid of me. I like the ride up, the singing turrets and all that, I don't like how I'm in a feild with no city around me, or no building around me. If she was going to get rid of me, why not leave me close to a city? I really think they should make a free Portal three game of me getting back into the building, hanging out with GLados, Wheatley coming back and apologizing and bemcoming friends with us again, and let me be able to go out to the city, live in a house, and be able to visit GLaDOS and Wheatley. I really want to see what happens after that. I don't like how GLaDOS got rid of me, and how there's no city near me, and how I don't know what happens after that. I really want Valve to make another Portal.  What do you think?

Definitely a must buy. Portal 2 is a wonderful puzzle game with a funny and heartwarming story. In Portal 2 you learn more about Aperture Science in the past. And it's not like those mostly dull CW TV shows where you learn more about superheroes when they started. It is actually interesting because you learn more about GlaDOS herself (who she is and why she is insane). It is impossible to play this game without smiling from laughter as GlaDOS and the hilariously stupid Wheatley attempt to kill you. You will want to stop progressing through the game just to hear Wheatley try to 'hack' a machine. Most of the time if you wait enough Wheatley will continue attempting to figure out how to get out of a certain situation. For example you will hear his hacking techniques where he makes a list of the objects in a locked room including a computer, the floor, and objects not in the room like pens.  Portal 2 has levels but there are parts of the game where you get out of the test room number i formula and explore the back of the facility in search of a way out. The test rooms themselves are very accessible. To test a hypothesis you don't have to do alot of work, where in other FPSes with puzzle elements you would have to backtrack the whole level to find one stupid cracked wall that looks different from other ones that you have to shoot. They also give you alot of hints in the design of the level. It's kind of hard to describe but the design of the levels (like railings on certain platforms or black spaces on certain places) scratches off some theories with wrong answers on how to solve some of the puzzles.  There is also coop but I have not played it yet. I have looked at the level editor and the great thing about it is that you cannot submit a level unless there is a solution. That definitely means that all the levels in the workshop are genuine.  This is a game that everyone can play and would want to play to the end. I wish Valve would make single player games again. Definitely get it and play it!

Portal 2 is an innovative puzzle game with a hilarious, well written narrative attached to a very interesting story. Details about the game's backstory and plot are interweaved throughout the game in hilarious and sometimes surprisingly ominous ways, and the game as a whole was nothing short of incredible in almost every respect. Even though I heard nothing but praise about this game before playing it myself, I was still surprised by just how fantastic it was. Portal 2 is nearly perfect, and I can't say that there's currently anything like it in the gaming world, nor can I say there ever will be in the future.   If you're wondering whether or not you should buy this game, the question you should really be asking youorself is whether or not you should buy this game as well as the original Portal, and the answer is yer. Oh my god, yes. Play the original Portal, then play Portal 2. Both of them are fantastic, and I would love nothing better than to describe them both and how beautifully well put together and utterly revolutionary they were in every respect, but to spoil anything about the experience would be a crime in itself. Please, purchase and enjoy these products right now if you haven't already.  Overall Review = 9.7/10 A masterpiece that's hardly a stone's throw away from perfect

After playing the first portal game, I wasn’t sure how they could make a second game without ruining the first, but after playing this game I realize that they could not have done a better job. The storyline is fantastic (I’m not gunna spoil it!) and all of the puzzles are challenging and fun! The mental satisfaction of solving one of the puzzles is great! You feel so dumb up to the point you figure out the puzzle chamber and it’s like a spark of satisfaction that feels good up to the point you walk into the next chamber and have ABSOLUTLY no idea how to solve it. The voice acting is fantastic as well, every character sounds EXSACTLY how you would expect and it really makes this game worth the money. One thing i did not expect when this game came out was the multi-player. Having an extra mind in the game with you solving puzzles that are impossible to complete alone is more fun than i have ever had in any multi-player game ever. There is no more I need to say about this game, it’s just a great buy! If you have a couple dollars rolling around then give this game a shot! I promise you won’t regret it!

If you enjoyed the first Portal game, there is no way you cannot love this one. If you never played the first Portal game, welcome to a virtual roller coaster ride. To start with the bad: it has a few weird console things like pre-rendered cutscenes, which are not as good as the way Valve normally does things, and looks like crap when running at resolutions over 720p. That and taking me 3.7 hours to finish single player on my first run-through (granted, I've played the first game so many times, I really never got stuck on a puzzle).  Looking past those few issues, the single player story: incredible. Most games you have maybe a 10-20 hour storyline, but only about 20-30% is pure fun. In Portal 2, the entire playtime is fun. Taking a look at Co-op play, it is flawlessly executed, and while none of the puzzles were overly challenging, they definitely were not easy. They were balanced basically perfectly for new players and old players alike.

So I haven't had a computer capable of running decent games in years. I've put off every game until I could afford a decent computer, and portal was part of that list of games that I had put off.  During the steam summer sale, I spent over 150 dolalrs on games and hardware (Steam link). Part of this bundle included Portal and Portal 2.   You can't really talk about Portal 2 without talking about Portal, and so I'd just like to say, if you haven't played either game yet, you need to get these games.  Both games were amazing, the characters terrificly crafted, everything was just terrific to me. I don't even like platformers, and more than once I was extremely frustrated with how difficult a level was and would have to find a guide online, but it was all worth it. I beat both games in two days, neglected my family, starved my dog, all for the cake.  If you are on the fence, jump on over. if you enjoy video games at all, you'll be happy with your choice.

Disclaimer: I beat the game on PS3 before I knew Steam existed. I bought it again, because it's that enjoyable to me. Also a few plot spoilers and an undetailed description of a scene in the game. Go to the final sentence to see the point of it.*  --Playing Portal 2. Fun, well written, etc.  I'm falling down one of Aperture's infamous chutes with a potato clock- battery- thing.   The little yellow light on the potato lights up.  'How are you doing? Because I'M a  potato .'  The potato is GlaDOS, the malicious AI that once controlled the facility before being usurped (with help from Chell, the player character) by Wheatley, an egotistical mo  ron sphere that wants to not be a mo  ron...  ...by killing me.   Me and my brave potato friend embark on a many- hours- long quest back to the top levels of Aperture Labs, listening to the likes of Cave Johnson's Lemon Speech (I'M THE MAN THAT WILL BURN YOUR HOUSE DOWN.  WITH THE LEMONS !), completing Gel Tests (Bouncy, Speedy, Portal-y), nearly getting my valiant potato eaten by birds (And yet somehow we're underground? Huh. Cavebird.), and finally, we make our exhausted way back to the top.   What was the point of all of this?  If you think you'll like it, you probably will.

Well, another Portal release come and gone. I finally beat this game, too, so now I feel obligated to make a recommend this game as well. Portal 2 picks up about 2 years(?) after Portal 1 left off after Chell was (ANTI-SPOILER CENSOR). You get the portal gun back, and you actually pair up with GlaDos. If only Wheatly didn't reasemble her! Anyway, the ending was pretty dramatic, funny, and pretty epic if you ask me (you see Chell's arms!). I have tried a bit of the co-op, which requires some communication with your partner, but word to the wise: there's a story that picks up where the single-player ends, so beat the SP first. They just added a level editor, which is pretty user friendly (note: the emancipation grids are called 'Fizzlers), and you get to upload them and stuff. All in all, Portal 2 is a good game to play, and it has some goodies to keep me sucked in for a while.

Begin with the game you woke up in a room which resembles an typical hotel room, then some banging on the door begins the great adventure of our heroine Chell. A sudden shake-off of the room which reveals the room is actually one container of 10 thousand people multi-complex. The show begins with an tremendous fashion. It appeals the player right away as if it is inviting them into the story.  And right away do you also feel the witty sarcasm which exists throughout the entire game. When the robot manager tell you: `This is art, stare at the art for 5 seconds.' and then plays classical music, it just makes me smile. The script writers are geniuses. The lines are comical but not too funny, and with a sense of dark humor. The robot themselves are always joking around with the death or termination of themselves, and sometimes to each other too. Almost childish but not overdone. Especially GLaDOS herself is a very charming character, I have to confess I fell in love with GLaDOS when she tried to talk Wheatley into a paradox, and mumbling 'dont think about it dont think about it'. It's just so cute.  The story and background setting are definitely deepened deliberately this time. When I played the first three chambers I was kind of worried they are just remaking Portal 1 - because I played 2 right after 1 so I could remember the puzzles as the same. Gladly they weren't! It's a fairly lengthy brand new game - about 8 hours - and every minute of it worths it. They put a lot of effort laying the background and showing the player how Aperture and the facility come to be. They laid huge architectural work for the game, I couldn't even imagine how big the facility is because it was so massive, there are so many rooms which you can't see the top end or the bottom end - which surprisingly reminds me of BioShock not at the time of playing but now. I've seen Valve done this large-world trick before in Half-Life 2, and I know they are getting good at it because this one is even better.  Music is great, not repetitive and well paced. Voice acting is tremendous, both Wheatley and GLaDOS.  The end game was also very good (and surprising!). I'm very happy that they didn't make the final boss very hard - after all, who would want to fight a difficult boss after solving all the puzzles? The tired player deserves a relaxed good show.  10/10, I haven't felt this kind of excitement for years, and Portal 2 brought it to me. It's a fine piece of work and I strongly recommended it.  Ps: I haven't played the multiplayer yet, but I heard it's very good too.

I'm not normally a person who gives out 10/10 reviews to any game or mod as I am a relatively hard person to please, but some titles deserve nothing more!  Portal is a game series that I avoided like the plague when it was first announced by Valve, for no other reason than for the fact that it was popular and had nothing to do with the Half-Life series (or so I thought), so I just let is pass me like the wind. Eventually, I came across a sale on Steam that had the Entire Valve package for less than £30.00, which included the Portal Series, so since I had paid for them, I figured I may as well try them and well, I was not disappointed!  I loved the first Portal game, even though it was short, it had everything that I good game should have! Great game-play and a great story, and Portal 2 really improved upon everything that Portal 1 had to offer. There are practically zero faults that I have with this game.  It just goes to show that you should never judge a book by its cover and that just because something is popular, doesn't mean you should automatically dismiss it. The great game-play, storyline and endless fan chambers really do make this game worth paying for. Great job to everybody involved, it takes a lot to please me, but this was no contest!

Portal 2 is one of the most memorable games I've played so far! The concept behind it seems boring at first but Valve couldn't have executed this concept into their game any better.   The characters in the campaign are amazing and one of the best I've seen so far in a video game, the bound you will have with these characters will be unbreakable. The level design is very well done and the story never seems to get boring, always something unpredictable, funny or dramatic will happen to keep your attention.   If the story line, which definetly is what makes this game so great, wasn't enough there is the co-op mode with workshop integration. The co-op mode takes place after the main story and is very well designed as well, you have much fun solving puzzles together with your partner in science. You can even steal your partner's head, smash him with spike plates or drop him in toxic waste. The workshop has many well made maps and original concept you can play if you completed the main co-op mode (which isn't that big).   This all will ensure that you'll have over 100 hours of potention playtime.   I highly recommend this games to anyone!!

How could I have played 87 hours (and counting) of Portal 2 you ask? The answer is this simple truth: Portal 2 is epic.   This ingenious game created by Valve contains a unique story that offers just as authentic gameplay. There's witty humor, intriguing suspense, brilliant dialogue, plot twists, and Aperture Laboratory shenanigans. There's also a co-op mode which opens up even more possibilities to have an incredibly fun time in Portal 2.   Yes this game can be horribly frustrating. But it's for your own good because Portal 2 makes you smarter. Yes, smarter. There is no mindless shooting in this game. Instead there is intricate puzzles that will get that noggin of yours thinking away.  I could rant on forever about this phenomenal game but I'd be wasting your gameplay time. So finish up reading this and start testing!

Like the first game, Portal 2 showcases unique gameplay with impressive polish. The puzzles are smart, the story is engaging, and everything works in gameplay. Co-op is excellently designed, with very few spots that can really stump players for long. Replayability is somewhat limited after figuring out the solutions, but Workshop support means you can play a multitude of single-player and co-op community levels. If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This game Portal 2 is amazing puzzle and adventure game, a sequel of the first game Portal that was hugely successful.    Story:  You are a test subject called Chell in an underground testing facility called Aperture Science. Since the last game “Portal” after you killed GLaDOS (Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System) Aperture Science has been filled with vines, weeds, dirt and other junk. At the start you meet a personality core called Wheatley, you both want to escape from the collapsing Aperture Science. After awhile you and Wheatley have to go through GLaDOS’s Chamber, where she is broken and deactivated. But you and Wheatley pull some… well a lot… well all the switches turning GLaDOS back on, she grabs you and sends you through test chamber, after test chamber, after test chamber   Character:  The Characters in Portal 2 are memorable, with fantastic voice acting making you love the characters (even if they are against you). The Characters make you feel emotion, like feeling sorry for them and getting angry at them etc. The Characters have great and interesting character progression, and interesting backstories. The characters can make you laugh with funny humor (mainly Cave Johnson).   Models/Textures:  The models and textures in Portal 2 and improved a lot, the personality cores looks have been changed, now they look more realistic. The textures around the test chambers aren’t that white anymore, now looking brown because a lot of time has pasted since the last time you were in the these test chambers. The textures overall look pretty realistic, giving more life to Portal 2. The models are also very well made. GLaDOS has also gotten a makeover, making here able to express emotion not just through here words, but now here eyes.   Music:  The Portal 2 music is very atmospheric, making you feel boxed in and alone. The music in Portal 2 is noticeable different in style to the original Portal.   Easter Eggs/Secrets:  There are plenty of Easter eggs and secrets to find in Portal 2, and the return of the Doug Rattmann dens.   Conclusion:  In conclusion Portal 2 is a fantastic sequel to Portal. It has a great story, characters, textures and models. The ending is interesting and good, and has great puzzles to solve and different environments. I would say this is my favorite game I’ve played so far.   This Game gets a 10/10    Sorry for any spelling mistakes in this review.

I still love this game even after having spent 65 hours with it.  The singleplayer experience is amazing; although the game takes place in a totally wrecked Aperture Laboratories, alluding to the - spoiler alert - destruction of GLADOS in  Portal , the plot of  Portal 2  remains independent, allowing the game to stand alone well.  In the game, the player is greeted by Wheatley, a spherical character who guides you through the Aperture Laboratories facility. As the game progresses, he/she is introduced to the game's identifying elements: the isolation placed upon the player by the enviroment, the Portal Gun, and GLADOS.  The player feels incredibly alone in this game: aside from Wheatley and GLADOS, the tester's assistant's voice and Cave Johnson's voice are the only other additional human elements in the game. He/she is left to solve the many puzzles that obstruct your path one after the other. As the game progresses, he/she is introduced to more and more puzzle elements, leading toward challenging 'test chambers' by the end of the game. The dreary soundtrack and lack of noise from Mother Nature leave the player to himself/herself and to solving the puzzle. The world manages to immerse the player in the deserted yet oddly realistic world that is Aperture Laboratories.  Solving 'test chambers' relies on the player utilizing the Portal Gun to the fullest. The Portal Gun, introduced to the player early in the game, allows him/her to teleport to various locations within a chamer in order to solve it. Passing through these chambers requires creativity, out-of-the-box thinking, and coordination: portals summoned by the Portal Gun maintain the velocity of anyone or anything flying through them.  GLADOS is a main character in the game but is not the guiding light to the plot like in  Portal . In  Portal 2 , the guiding light in the plot lies between the conflict with Wheatley and GLADOS; as the player advances in the game, he/she will learn what fueled this conflict and what its impact is on the story.  When one is finished with the singleplayer,  Portal 2  has additional content to keep the user busy. Challenge Mode offers the player the chance to complete an already solved puzzle in the fastest and most efficient way possible, focusing on using as little time and as few Portals as possible.  In addition, the game's multiplayer mode is as solid as the singleplayer mode. The multiplayer is an extension to the singleplayer story; the main characters are GLADOS and her two robotic test subjects Atlas and P-Body. Atlas and P-Body are tasked with working together to solve 'test chambers' that are otherwise unsolvable with only one person around. The emphasis on coordination is vital to winning the game; since the story is strictly two-man co-op, it is imperative that both players have an idea of what to do.  TIP: Keep a voice chat with your co-op buddy. One way of starting a voice chat is by clicking the arrow in the Steam overlay's chat window and clicking 'Start Voice Chat.'  After completing both the singleplayer and multiplayer game, the adventure does not stop. Ever since the game was linked with the Steam Workshop with the Perpetual Testing Iniative update in 2011, users have been submitting their own test chambers left and right. Many of these chambers are challenging and take liberties with level standards as well as throw in their own style in utilizing the game's elements. The game provides a level creation tool which is rather comprehensive; however, more sophisticated levels can be developed using the Hammer tool, a piece of software found in the Source SDK (Windows only).  The only problem I found with this game is that certain puzzles were hard; however, these puzzles were hard simply because I wasn't a great problem solver that time. Upon watching a walkthrough for the chambers I was stuck on, I realized that there was a practical solution to each and every one of them. Playing more puzzles allows players to become better at this game, and there are no levels in either of the main games that involve impossible-to-execute solutions.  I recommend this game highly to anyone interested in puzzle games in general. Valve has made this game have well-crafted and solvable levels and worlds, amazing aesthetics, a great soundtrack, and a sense of eternal fun. It is worth investing the twenty dollars as the experience is  truly  unforgettable.    Portal 2  is a puzzle game classic of the 2000's that should not be missed.   10/10. A+. 100%. P.S. In multiplayer, players can let their Atlas and/or P-Body characters wear hats (which is seen frequently in  Team Fortress 2 , another game by Valve).

Even if you aren't a 'hardcore puzzle fan', you will love this game. I know this is probably what everyone else says, but come on it's Portal, you have to play it. The puzzles are challenging, and make you think in ways you haven't thought of before, where you have to think outside the box to solve each puzzle. The best part about the puzzles though, is that after a while you don't have a guide, and have to learn new aspects of the puzzle by yourself, even though before you had had someone to help you through. The storyline is amazing, making you feel as if you were inside the game, and giving you a personalized experience although millions have played it already. I'd rate this game 10/10 for all of the things being mentioned above.

Portal 2, *sigh* where do I start, Portal 2 is the best game, I still play it now, I played through the story so much I remembered how to solve each test once I enterd the room, the Co-Op story is just as good, I don't play it that much, but Valve did an amazing job of making puzzles with 4 portals.  Then there is the community maps, the Single player maps are good (unless they are not) there are a lot of good mappers for Portal 2 (even myself, I'm not good, but I do make good maps) anyway, then there is the Co-op community maps, they (just like the SP maps) are good if the mapper is good at making it, I've seen a lot of terrible chambers when I played SP maps, then there are the amazing mappers that feel like they should have worked on the game.  Now, let's move onto the In-game map editor, it's super simple to use, and there are videos on YouTube or there are guides in the steam workshop to help you, heck, there are even some Portal 2 Peti mods if you don't want to use Hammer (I call it that because it's easy to remember) now, Hammer is a more advanced mapping tool, but you can do so much more with it then peti (why is that Valve?) and there are YouTube videos and Steam guides to teach you, I have started to map in hammer, it's hard at first, but once you get the hang of it, it's a piece of cake.  Anyway, I hope this review helped you decied if you should buy the game or not, if you do buy it, I hope to see you in the Community maps, and who knows, you might be the next popular mapper, Have Fun.

It's the sequel to Portal, what more is there to say?     Seriously, though, it improves on Portal in every way and has coop and custom maps by the community. The new gel mechanics are pretty cool as well. Overall it plays exactly like Portal did, as a first-person puzzler. Portal 2 is truly incredible and stands alongside Half-Life 2 in Valve's hall of great games. Setting is even better than the first game, as it's still Aperture Science, but broken down and depressing. Portal 2 is also quite a bit longer than the original, and the story is constantly twisting and changing while incorporating the trademark humor the series is known for. Portal 2 is one of the best games of all time, as far as I'm concerned. 9.75/10, do buy.

Although the game is more than 5 years old, Portal 2 is still good to this day. The puzzles, (as long as you don't know the solution) are very intuitive and thought provoking. Not to mention, that the addition to the gel, gravity beams, etc. Are interesting and is a great puzzle mechanic besides just cubes, buttons, and portals. The graphics are still acceptable to this day, but concidering Portal 2 came out in 2007, it was amazing at the time. The addition of co-op is ingenious, irrelevant if you actually have a friend to play with or not, should still be a welcome thing. Not to mention, when you DO have a friend to play with, and assuming they actually cooperate (Get it, co-op?), it is very fun, probably even more than the single player game. Speaking of single player, the main campain is very interesting, and the story is interesting, with a midway plot twist, and technically a side-plot. Completing the game, (In other words, getting all of the acheivments) Is very possible and actually kind of fun to do. It's almost like trying to find all of the content compared to actually using ~ amazing skills ~ to get any of the achievments. (Except for the time trails). The community maps can add difficulty to those who actually want the difficulty, instead of the achievments. What a hard, almost impossible puzzle? Look through some of the community maps. Or make one, that works too. Anyways, the music works really well with the atmosphere of the game. The music typically comes up whenever you happen to come across a puzzle, especially in the test chambers. What I loved about the music in Portal 2 is when you are flying through the air, whether because of the blue or orange gel, or because of the launch pads, overlapping music that would sound awesome on its own matching the existing music and it sounds great! The music itself sounds amazing to. The techno music fits the futuristic, robot apocalyptic atmosphere perfectly. The atmosphere itself makes the game just standout not only as a puzzle game, but as an adventure game, too. One of the main reasons I didn't go insane while I was trying to figure out a puzzle is the story, which is amazing on its own right. The story, (No spoilers don't worry) is set in a robotic apocalyptic setting, where the robots have taken over. You are a lab rat, going through experiment after experiment. Things have changed since the first game though. Everything is rotten, plants are overgrowing alot of it, and everything just seems discombobulated (is that a word?); and the atmosphere reflects this perfectly.  Overall, the game is very good, but for me, it was short lived. But, with Co-op and community maps, and the workshop enabled, this game can last quite a while. Even if you do play the entire game in one sitting, I guarantee that one sitting would last for more than 24 hours.  Edit: I was really bad at analyzing games more than a year ago. Don't feel liking deleting or changing this though. idk.

8/10 Good continuation off of Portal, also has some fun and challenging chambers. The Perpetual Testing Initiative also lets players create their own chambers without having to know much about Hammer or any of those fancy things. There's only two parts that annoy me: 1. Controller support. They say it has FULL support for 'em, but most of the UI of the Testing Initiative does not work, like in example when you've already subscribed to one or more chambers, pressing DPAD UP or DOWN or moving the joystick at all after having selected 'Play singleplayer chambers' does totally nothing. Also, if you were to accidentally select Robot Loadout on the main menu with the controller, go get your mouse. You will not be able to exit it with your gamepad. The mouse isn't hidden while using the controller (in-menus), which is honestly  VERY  annoying since when in menus, it usually selects what's in the middle of the screen. In gameplay itself, however, it's good. You can at least customize the controls, but sometimes, it doesn't work and you gotta toggle between Default 1 and Custom until it finally updates. The part that you can't make chambers with the controller is understandable...enough.  2. Splitscreen Co-op on one computer. It just throws you right into the game, completely ignoring wether you're a CS:GO pro or a COD noob. No co-op intro. No nothing. You don't get any keybind/controller hints in the intro of the game like you do in the retail version, either...you gotta figure out how to go back to bed yourself. Not that that troubles me, but...  'For your convenience, all the test chambers are now unlocked.'  -The Announcer    Now, for the pros. It's got a good story line, continues off of Portal, except several years after 'murdering' GLaDOS, and has a round Personality Sphere called Weedly, who apperently does not smoke. (Yes, that was a lie. His real name is Wheatley) Only thing bad about the story is they have no more cake. It is never mentioned. NO. CAKE!  Graphics-wise, great. To be 2011. This isn't exactly a next-gen game, but it's okay. Only thing I don't get, is how you shoot Portals. The gun doesn't even have a bloody trigger. It doesn't have a clean trigger either. Hand transplant?  There's lots of new gameplay on here, including in the intro, which includes old chambers from Portal and some new ones which are original. Except on certain chambers later in the game, I just sat there. And started at all corners of a chamber. I was like 'What the (BEEP) am I supposed to do!?' and forced myself after 2 hours of thinking to go to the Portal 2 wiki just to find out the answer was obvious. That's what I usually call the 'Legend of Zelda effect'. Not saying you'll end up like that, but just might happen. Certain chambers just require you to act fast as *BEEP*, so if you're 'simple-minded, old, or just irradiated in such a way the future should  not  start with you,' or don't know how to move a camera, don't play this.  Total rating (ignoring the lack of controller support on most areas of the UI): 8/10. Also, a quick note...if you own two Wireless xbox 360 gamepads and have an adapter, or own 2 wired gamepads, you can play splitscreen co-op with yourself if you're a loner. Just saying. Or real-life friends. That's just if you don't have Steam friends to play with...

I HATE PUZZLE GAMES...  But this game is amazing. The jokes are actually kinda funny, the story is too complex to explain, yet basic enough to follow, but what I love most about Portal 2 that makes it so much better than any other puzzle game in my opinion is that rarely will you ever just 'hit a wall' on what to do next, and if you do, you either just need to take a harder look around, or you need to just play around with the portal mechanics and eventually you'll get it. I did find myself, however, annoyed a few times because I was stuck on some of the none-test chambers (I'm trying to be vague so I don't ruin any of the story), and usually when I'm stuck I just need to think about where I'm going (for example if I need to get on to a high platform where the exit is and there aren't any portal servers there I know I need to look for a place to gain momentum), but sometimes I didn't even I didn't even know that (luckily that was only twice). One more thing I'd like to mention, is that I don't exactly have a gaming Computer (my graphics card, the hardware mainly responsible for FPS, Is an integrated Intel HD Graphics 3000), yet, this game runs smoothly with the texture quality on high, the shader on high, and and everything else on normal (also I don't mean the kind of 'smoothly' people use when they have a really bad computer and they get 20 FPS on a game as oppose to 8, I'm talking about 40-60 FPS with a graphics card meant for surfing the internet on mid - high graphics)

Sequel to one of the best puzzle games ever, Portal 2 expands on everything and showcases Chell as she once again tries to escape from Aperture Science, this time with the help of the personality core Wheatley.  Often times the first game in a series is the best, but Portal 2 takes everything that makes the first game great and adds more to it. There are a lot more levels and new mechanics to master:  -Excursion Funnels - beams that allow you to travel along the path they create. -Aerial plates, which launch you. -Light bridges - they create a bridge made of light which you can walk on. -Gels - liquids that have different effects such as making you faster or helping you jump higher. And these are just to name a few.  The boss battle keeps the same style from the first game.  Portal 2 also contains a CO-OP player campaign which requires you and another player. You take the role of either Atlas or P-Body which are created by Glados. Levels are specially desgined to make use of the 2 player count.  It's a fun game that you can play alone or with friends and I recommend it.

Dustforce truly is a work of art. I don't mean that lightly. The way it's animated plus its music gives it that title in my book. I can find myself playing one level for an hour, maybe even hours at a time. The frustration of losing levels is filled with relaxation and calmness because of the ambient music. The way the levels are crafted is truly mindblowing. They had a system in which you had to perfect a level to earn a key, and you would use that key to earn more levels. In layman's terms, to earn more levels, you had to perfect current levels. They ditched that and added an XP system in which you gain more XP to earn a key the more levels you play and perfect. I'm very glad they added this system and was skeptical about buying it. But now that I did buy it, I do not regret it even for a second. One thing I really love about this game is how you don't have to unlock base levels. In a sense, this game is open world. That sense is that many levels are available to you, and you can choose whether you want to advance into more challenging levels, or stay where you're at. To get an S in completion, you have to sweep up EVERY leaf, and to get an S in Finesse, you have to maintain your combo throughout an entire level.   Another thing I absolutely enjoy about Dustforce is its expasive community. There are lots of Community Workshop maps for you to sharpen your skills on, and lots of people who can set a good example. I'm sure most of the people who get best times on all the levels have a Youtube channel, so you can probably catch them there. The community may or not be active, but it sure is good and friendly.  Overall, in terms of gameplay, music, artstyle, animation, and difficulty (it's not an easy game, but it's not that hard of a game either. It just depends on how much you want to play it), I rate this game:  10/10 BUY THIS GAME.

A very worthy sequel to the first Portal game. Nice story, great characters, lot of humor, nice additions to the puzzles. I am glad to see that not only indie developers can achieve such a level of creativity. The game may be a tad easy but hey, you can have your worth with the community maps.  My only complain is that you don't have the feeling that you are in a human body: you are just a floating camera with no visible arms or legs, no head bobbing. Dark Messiah of Might and Magic has implemented all these features perfectly, and it is based on the Source engine so there is no excuse for Valve. Moreover, the character doesn't make any sound, not even a grunt after a long fall or when getting wounded. All this breaks a bit the immersion, and that's a sad thing.

If you like portal, you'll LOVE this game! And if you don't have portal 1, you won't like it NEARLY as much as this game. While the original only had cubes, buttons, fizzlers turrets and energy pellets, THIS one replaces pellets with lazers, and adds NEW functions! There's aerial faith plates, tractor beams that go in both directions, lazerfields, repulsion gel, prepulsion gel, conversion gel, cleansing gel which is basically water, new characters, a new co-op mode, and an EXCELENT plot-twist half-way through. I won't tell you what that is, so you can find out for yourself, but believe me, IT'S GOOD! And you can make your own levels now too! All in all, the best sequel for the best puzzle game.

Hello, and welcome to Aperture Science Enrichment Center. We are here to provide you with an amazing puzzle game, with a remarkable story line, voice acting and mechanics. Portal 2, successor of the highly acclaimed Portal, is a game where you... use portals. This time, Valve brings us a more in-depth story arch, with more puzzle rooms and more difficulty. As Chell, you will try to fight your way through the testing chambers of Aperture Science facility, using only your wits and your portals. A game where you can't just rush through it, you need to think. This time, they added a co-op mode, where you play as 2 little friendly robots, doing test chambers together. This mode works great with this already awesome game. For all of you out there reading this, just buy it. You won't regreat it! 10/10
