The first criticism is the same as my criticism of Portal 1:  'This game pulled me out of immersion within the first few minutes. I like to be able to imagine I am the character in a game, in the scenario created, and escape into that world for a while. Half Life 2 failed for me, and Portal made the same errors. In this case: the game begins with you waking up. And you seem to have had radical surgery, with metal bolted onto your bones. Don't you think you would examine that? Check your legs? Is it bolted or strapped on? Could it be removed and you restored to a normal body, or are you permanently disfigured? Does it hurt to walk on it? To fall 50 feet and land on it? The game doesn't answer any of this, meaning I was immediately removed from the character. Either she had information that hadn't been shared with the player (making it difficult to _be_ her in the game), or she somehow doesn't notice or comment upon the fact that she may have been mutilated in her sleep (again, making it impossible to empathise with the character). This could have easily been rectified by a few seconds of close-up, maybe a wince; perhaps later a comment on it, or a sign about the surgery. To gloss over something that would be so major in a person's life is bizarre.'  I also noticed (which I don't remember from Portal 1) that picking up the portal gun now gives you X-ray vision. You can see where portals are even when they're out of sight, through walls. It is often confusing (sometimes they looked like the gun sights); unnecessary (it wasn't useful to me in the slightest); and it made no sense (the character wasn't looking through special sights on the gun or anything like that). I wouldn't have minded if it was a feature you could turn off, but I couldn't find any such setting in the menu.  Again, the actual puzzling is generally okay, but weird things like that kept distracting me.

I have mixed feelings about this one. On one hand it is a solid piece of engineering and those ten hours I spent with it were fun, if annoying at times. Yet remembering how revolutionary the first Portal was, it’s hard not to blame Portal 2 for its lost potential. A bigger budget and a bigger team, but the result is an uninspired sequel riding on the popularity of the original.  The story in the first Portal , and the progression of environments made sense. First you where a test subject, then you escaped and made your own way around the facility to finally fight GLaDOS. Hints that something was off with Aperture were subtle and built tension. The length was just right, you could complete it in one breathtaking sitting.  In Portal 2 you simply “follow the rail” as the helpful robot with an awful British accent (and forced humor) tells you. References to the original are in-your-face, everything lacks subtlety or any kind of suspense. At least puzzles rise up in difficulty nicely, if a bit slowly. It’s hard to get used to hand-holding popups and NPCs suggestions though. It’s a puzzle game, I want to figure this stuff out, OK?  Sure, the visuals are nicer, but that doesn’t really add anything to the game play. Unfortunately from the technology point of view Portal 2 has a major flaw: the loading screens. Loading between levels takes longer than in the original and there are now immersion-destroying separate loading screens. Both chase sequences in the game are also broken up with the loading screens. The funny thing is: elevators are still here. Yep, Portal 2 has both an elevator and a loading screen between levels.  Ultimately it’s just more of the same. Portal 2 doesn’t push any boundaries, it’s a high fidelity bonus pack to Portal. Sadly it’s nowhere near as important as the first Portal. You can go to  Portal Memories  to explore interesting environments or to  Portal Pro  for some real challenge.  Funny thing is that I’ve seen this before. It’s the same kind of thing that happened to BioShock. It was supposed to be a worthy successor to System Shock 2. Developers of both Portal 2 and BioShock made the game accessible to a wide audience. Both games achieved the same level of “critical acclaim” (top spot on metacritic in their year of release). Yet both lost the soul of its predecessor.  If you’re looking for a spiritual successor then it’s clearly somewhere else.

There was a brief period during which I was obsessed with Portal 2. Not because of engrossing gameplay, or story, or characters, but because I kept trying to comprehend how the same people that made the masterpiece that is Portal 1 could make this. Puzzles are greatly simplified and less interesting, and seem to exist purely to funnel the player from overwrought setpiece to overwrought setpiece. Very few of the game mechanics are used to an extent that makes their existence meaningful. The game tries too hard to be funny in every detail, and fails, creating grating characters and an unfocused setting. However, the co-op manages to provide a more satisfying experience in both gameplay and atmosphere, and the perpetual testing initiative is a very cool idea with an easy-to-use but powerful editor. There's still some genius within this package, it's just not given the time to shine. 5/10

Review based on single player mode only, in 2014. With a metascore of 95, this is certainly one of the most overrated game. The game is not bad but had several issues. Actually in most areas I would give the game a 7/10. I don't see any one single aspect that I would rate at 9.  - Technically the game is OK, the 3D 'Source' engine is serviceable but a bit dated. Most items and environments have very geometrical shapes, don't expect fancy light or particles effects. More annoying are the many loading times even for small levels. Before AND after each level there is a similar 'lift' sequence, which quickly get repetitive and boring, and only add extra loading times.  - The designers made commendable efforts on the gfx style and story telling. The robotics voice acting are a mix of joke/taunt/background story/hint, however I don't find they were relly funny, but rather annoying. Nevertheless you shouldn't turn the voices off for fear of missing a helpful hint. Overal I wasn't captivated by the atmosphere and the plot, and all the cutscenes was more a distraction than anything else  - There are no manual or tutorial, instead there are some visual and speech hints, but this is the kind of game where understanding the rules and mechanisms is part of the puzzles. Not a big issue, but sometimes a cause for irritation.  - Basically each level is a small closed room where you must open and reach the exit. Rooms are mostly empty, and only contain a very few items relevant to the solution. Indeed the first puzzle are rather easy once you get the idea of the game. Then in the second third of the game, the levels become larger and more open, and feels like an abandonned factory. This introduce an element of exploration. Unfortunately the environment is completly passive (except for a very obvious levers), and even if you explore every remote corners you won't find anything of interest. In the end you roam long corridors and scaffolders, which only dilute the puzzle solving aspect of the game. And most of this part is pretty linear and boring with many repetitive puzzles, and some dexterity challenges.   - The final part of the game revert back to the puzzle rooms and is more interesting with some good and challenging puzzle.  - The single player mode took me 11h to complete. There is also a cooperative 2 player mode which is a different experience (of little interest for me as I have a poor connection and play mostly solo). Additionaly there are many users created contents which add to the experience. Considering the price this is a decent amount of content. But overal I find the game didn't lived up to the hype and there are other puzzle game that I found more enjoyable.

Some of the negative reviews here aren't too detailed, so I'll try my best to change that. I'd like to offer some valid reasons why I can't recommend this game. Of course they're my personal observations, and the issues won't affect everyone, but they could affect *you*.   Major Issue: Bugs   Bugs in over 35% of the wretched puzzle rooms. Whether it was pixel hunting for the correct atom of usable wall to pop a portal on, or the game presenting busted mechanics you cannot work around as there is only one solution to everything. Sometimes repeating the same action five times would result in four failures and one success. Most of the time I had to reload an older save to start that area all over again, hoping that this time the puzzle would be functional. In a puzzle game, these bugs are not so much game-breaking as fun-breaking. I only realised something was amiss when I consulted a YouTube walkthrough, and found out I was doing the right thing but the game was bugged.   I'm now stuck on (what feels like) the nadir of the game. I'm in a glitched puzzle where Stephen Merchant keeps yammering at me in an attempt to be funny. This room (Wheatley puzzle 17 I think, blue tunnel of light going horizontally) has murdered the game for me. I just don't have the interest in it to bother completing this room. Tried the video walkthroughs, but guess what? The wall others can use, I can't! To play a game where I can't tell when it's bugged or not is literally gaming torture.   Second smaller gripe: Stephen Merchant's voice acting. Holy flurking schnit, who thought this was a good idea?! I'm English, but this man's voice gets on my nerves, let alone his awful attempt at jokes and ad-libbing. With all the reloading I've had to do, I've heard his rotten material probably sixty times more than other players.  Multiplayer wasn't free of bugs either, and after trying it once I didn't return to it for a very good reason. Whether it was lag or bugs/glitches, bits of these puzzles didn't work either. Marvellous!    Summation   If you are intent on getting the game, I'd heartily recommend getting it discounted. Of course, you may not experience these bugs. My friends didn't - their run through was completely fine. Nor can I explain why over 50% of the game bugged out. The faulty turret puzzle was the first major issue that halted progress for days, as the only cure was reloading old saves before I had entered a 'bugged' area. Can you imagine how much of a pain that was, having to reload whole areas because one room's puzzle wouldn't let me through? There are no backdoors or workarounds, so when something goes wrong, it completely blocks your progress.  I really wanted to enjoy this game, as there are some really good elements. I loved controlling the liquid so I could make new portals. I didn't have a problem with this element at all, and it was lovely to experience it working properly. The super-bouncy areas were a lot of fun too. I also enjoyed seeing the roots of Aperture Science, and GLAdOS's history.   The bugs utterly ruined it for me. You can't afford to have bugs in a puzzle game that requires precision, timing, and thought from the player: It's like performing surgery with a carrot instead of a scalpel.

Unlike Portal 1, this one seems to have more of a focus on the story than the puzzles. It's still a good game, don't get me wrong, I just feel as though there could have been a little more emphasis on the puzzle aspect.  Though if you're looking for the parts that are heavily puzzle-based, they're in the co-op and in the user-created maps. Though I would still recommend going through the story mode.  I'd expect Portal 2 to have a longer lifespan than Portal 1, because there's lots of community maps out there, and people are always making more.

Lovely game involving puzzle-solving. Beautifully created maps. Would recommend buying it along side Portal 2, starting with Portal, then playing Portal 2, then playing the community-built maps on Portal 2. Community-built maps are very well created, I am impressed with the imagination of these creators! There are a wide range of fairly easy, but some very challenging ones! The actual game is quite short, like Portal, but there is a vast amount of community-built maps that you can spend days going through! It's also nice having Stephen Merchant keeping you company as you play! It's quite a quick game to play through, but entertaining none-the-less. Graphics-wise, it runs smoothly and perfectly on my early 2011 15 inch MacBook Pro. 10/10.

Portal was a fun game. It's simple controls and puzzle-based gameplay was something I hadn't seen in a first-person-shooter. Replacing enemies with lateral thinking, weapons with a portal gun, and all the anatagonists with a hyper-intelligent. Portal 2, however, doesn't just leave off where Portal ended. It takes where Portal ended and blows it up like the deathstar. I mean, it's one of those rare sequals that just leaves the original in the dust.   Waking up years after the first ends; the facility is in major disarray and GlaDOS is awake and still on a mission to kill you; for science! Rather than just a few puzzle rooms; this game has an entire facility. You finally get the unimaginable scope of how big the center was. And just when you think the game is over and you've defeated GlaDOS; well, the game is just getting started.   It's a game that redefined gaming; how you can take a bunch of really cool concepts and build not just a game out of it; but an entire world. Everyone's raved about this game, and for good reason; it's *THAT* good. It's also relatively family friendly; a rarity in todays gaming world. There's no real blood; you don't shoot anything but Portals; and the only time you die is when computerized turrets shoot you. Replace the violence for complex puzzles, add a big old glob of humor and you get Portal 2.  Buy it; play it. If you don't like it, then you're not a human.

When I first heard that Valve was going to make a sequeal to Portal, I was puzzled. 'How does one make a sequeal to such a short, fun and genre-defining game?' i asked. Valve's responce was 'Like this!' and showed me Portal 2.  Portal 2 is THE perfect game sequeal. The comedy is spot on, the game-play is perfect, I love this game so much, I played it's single player twice in the same week.  There's only 2 problems I have with P2. Firstly the music, the music is the 1st Portal made you felt like you was alone in the test chambers, no sign of life. The music in P2 is wonderful, don't get me wrong, but I don't get that same feeling of lonelyness I got in the last game due to it. Second problem, no references to cakes. It was a stample of the first game, why didn't they carry it to the second?  To conclude, buy both Portal and Portal 2 - YOU'RE MISSING OUT!

Portal 2 is one of those games that you come across once in a lifetime. It comes after Portal, which revolutionized the concept of running through portals to solve puzzles, which is an ingenious new take on gaming itself. I have never had a true favorite game until I played Portal 2. I admit I wasn’t so addicted to it at first, playing it off and on over the span of a few weeks. I honestly don’t know what grabbed me, but as soon as I blinked, I was addicted.   Now, I hear all the negativity that can come with saying that one thinks Portal 2 is better than Portal, but honestly, if I’d played Portal first, I wouldn’t have bought as much merchandise as I have sitting in my house right now. It’s the kind of game that makes you WANT to contribute as much of your money to as possible, because it’s that great of a game.   I love gifting this game to other Steam players (as well as Portal, but I particularly love giving out this game twice as much). It’s not a game many people should miss out on, and if you love puzzles and verbal abuse from an AI, this game is definitely something you should buy (even at full price).   GLaDOS is waiting. You monster.

99/100 for being THE Game of the Year, for its story, voice acting, humor, characters, unique puzzles, game play, etc. That being said, this is a must buy for anyone that loved the first Portal game or any other Valve games such as the Half Life series (which also takes place in the same universe / story). Although the single player campaign is only about 10 – 15 hours long depending on how good you are at solving puzzles, it definitely felt like the correct length. Furthermore, Portal 2 has co-op which adds cross platform play and an additional 5 – 10 hours of game play, which continues the story following the events of Portal 2 single player. Finally, as far as the story is concerned, the game answered almost all of my questions about Chell, Aperture Science, etc. Though we may not see a Portal 3, I have a good feeling that Half Life 3 will be here soon and I hope that we see Chell again someday!

This game is the very definition of awesome. What's even more awesome is that I got this during the summer sale for $9.99, saving me half of my Steam card. The story manages to be both hilarious and serious (but mostly hilarious). If someone were to ask me who was my favorite character, I wouldn't know where to start! Wheatley would have to be the worlds greatest moron for his horrible ideas and hilarious frantic personality. Not only is GLaDOS's name fun to type, but there has never been a better villain/antihero/AI. But Cave Johnson would have to be one of my favorites. He's the only supporting character who doesn't hate you or try to kill you, mainly because he's already dead! Also, his attempts to do anything legal or illegal for science make's his character even more likeable. Ok, back to the game. Even when your done with the singleplayer and co-op stories, there is still so much to do! The Perpetual Testing Initiative allows you to create your own test chamber (which might end up crappy) and upload it to the workshop for all to test it! This also gives you an Apperture nametag with your Steam profile pic to make it look like you work at Apperture. Also, you can here quotes from Cave Johnson (who, in this multiverse, is alive (another reason I love him)) whenever you start a community test. Cave's quote and the Apperture name tag make you feel like your an actual part of the story. This game is a 10/10.

Finally, with the recent addition of the Steam Workshop compatibility and very easy to use Puzzle Maker, the game is an absolute gem. Highly recommend it.

This is hands-down, without a question, my favorite game to come out in the last 10 years. An amazing sequel to a terrific game, Portal 2 was everything I hoped it would be and more. The 2-player co-op is a great way to continue the game with an added twist to the puzzle-solving aspect, and the ability to build & download custom maps is perfect for making the game playable long after completing the main story.

Quite simply: The best game I've ever played. This thing fires on all cylinders. Great story, great controls, great characters. The voice acting is incredible. Portal 2 succeeds at being a better game than it's predecessor. Several new puzzle-types as well as a move towards solutions that depend more on logic and experimentation than reaction time go a long way towards making Portal 2 fresh, new, and different. For me, however, it's the truly amusing story that unfolds around the player, told through amusing (one-sided) dialog and the environment itself that kept me going until the end.   There's also a ton more gameplay than the original. I wondered at the outset if this game was really worth the very large price hike over the original. Thankfully, it seems the Portal 2 team knew what to do with that budget.

Its puzzles are challenging without being unreasonable, and, once you're finished with the single-player mode, you can play one of the best co-operative experiences I have played. Valve cuts no corners and finds ways to make you care about everything from the major characters to the cubes used to solve puzzles. From the beginning of the single-player story to the end of the co-op mode, Portal 2 is an unforgettable experience.

First game I got on Steam, and I've not reviewed it yet. It's time I did. This is not a game. This is a work of art. Valve struck gold in 2007 with the release of The Orange Box, a package which indluded games like Half-Life 2 and the episodes, Team Fortress 2, and Portal. Portal was an experiment, and yet was acclaimed as one of the most original games of that year. Developement of a sequel began right away. Usually it's difficult to live up to such an incredible game in a sequel, but Portal 2 showed just how good a sequel can be. An extended story, more characters and character development, and the almighty GLaDOS. The puzzles were increased in quantity, quality, and length. The gameplay was suberb, the story was even better, managing to not take itself seriously in some parts, and still managing to be serious where it needs to be. All in all, 9.9/10. Why 9.9? Because I never rate a game 10.

A good game. Some of its puzzles are capable of giving one a headache, however they are all doable for an averagely intelligent player. Despite the fact that the game is focused on solving physics-based puzzles only, it does not get boring. Almost every new test chamber introduces new elements, which requires the player to try different approaches. A nice feature is the multi-player co-op mode which allows the player to be tested together with a friend. The game looks very well-made and detailed. It is hard to find any bugs in it, which I always like to do out of curiosity. The plot is definitely a bit more complex than in the game's prequel, and it is also often filled with humor, which is another plus. All in all, I believe it is one of the best games made by Valve so far, and I would certainly recommend it to everyone; except obviously children for whom it would be definitely too difficult.

“Well done. Here are the test results: You are a horrible person. I’m serious, that’s what it says: “A horrible person.” We weren’t even testing for that. Don’t let that horrible-person thing discourage you. It’s just a data point. If it makes you feel any better, science has now validated your birth mother’s decision to abandon you on a doorstep.” – GLaDOS  In Portal 2, you (Chell) find yourself in a hotel room of sorts where you just woke up from hibernation. The story element and the humor from the characters you become involved with are truly what make the game great. I find the puzzle element to be simply a bonus. I won’t give away what happens in Portal 2, you’ll have to find out for yourself. I will say however that GLaDOS does make a comeback and you are introduced to a humorous AI program named “Wheatley.”  The game is much, much longer than its predescesor…you’ll find yourself playing this game for at least a few hours. Some of the puzzles were tricky, especially the later ones that brought lasers and different kinds of slime into the mix. The new features and environments help keep the game fresh while the story unfolds to its final conclusion.  For those of you who enjoy teaming up with a friend, you’ll be happy to know that there is a Co-Op mode that allows two players to tackle puzzles together. The Co-Op mode was designed separately from the main game so the puzzles you and your partner will face are completely new and just as likely to leave you scratching your head. Each player gets a portal gun, meaning you can have up to four portals in the test chambers at once. Most puzzles are designed around this, making you both coordinate your portals and movements in order to advance to the next room.  Easy to recommend to anyone who enjoys puzzles and interacting with psychotic AIs.

To start out with, Portal 2 breaks the mold when it comes to sophomoric sequels. P2 gives the player a richly deeper story dive into the Appature Science facility further cementing the story crafting of Valve. The game is full exhilarating moments and witty comedy including the top notch performance by Stephen Merchant.   The addition of the multiplayer gameplay is something very common these days, except Portal 2 adds a different twist to with this one. The multiplayer environment allows 2 players to join together to tackle a myriad of 'test chambers' specifically designed for 2 players.   This game is a great mixture of fun and story. A true must have for gamers of any level.

Portal was sort of a little experiment of a huge company. That’s why success of the first part of the Portal was a surprise even for the VALVE. Therefore seriously question arose about the Portal 2. And what we got? Let's see.  　STILL ALIVE?  　　The game begins with the fact that Chell along with her new partner, personality module Wheatley, is trying to escape from an abandoned Aperture Science laboratory. Throughout the game, the plot makes a interesting twists. Individual deserves compliments perfect finale, after which there remain only a warm feeling. In Portal 2 no epic stories, huge explosions, incredible action, or the salvation of humanity. Instead, there is a charismatic characters, intelligent humor and interesting puzzles.  　ONE IS GOOD, BUT TWO IS BETTER  　　One of the achievements of the new Portal has been the emergence of the cooperative. Co-op story is a continuation of the plot of the single player. At first I thought that the only difference of the cooperative is the presence of two players with portal-guns, instead of one. In fact, the cooperative has unique ideas. Many puzzles solving quite differently. I advise you not to play cooperative with a random person (there is that possibility), and play it with a good friend.  　ENDLESS TESTS  　　In game was added a level editor, so anyone can create their own test chambers or try to play the levels of other players. To be honest, most of the player-created levels are too simple or ridiculous. But there is sufficient interesting maps (and some of them really hard). Portal 2 - A Unique Masterpiece: I'm gonna try to do something that no one ever seems to do, which is write a serious reveiw. Of course, that means that its gonna look either really cheesy or cool, probably both...  I first got Portal 2 on the Xbox 360, and probably got a good 50 hours or so out of it, finishing the single player and multiplayer campaigns. Then, I saw it on computer, and saw that it had a level editor, so I bought it on sale, and essentially payed 5$ for the editor. And now I have over 200 hours on it. That alone speaks for how much I love this game.   Gameplay: The gameplay is incredibly unique, and very fun. Everything you do in this game revolves around portals. The game's tutorial doesn't feel like one at all, and teaches you the beginings of 'Thinking with Portals'. The tutorial is in 3 parts over the games first chapter, but its more like an exploration of the concept than a tutorial. First, you use buttons to activate preset portals, then you get a gun that can shoot one portals, then you get the true Portal Gun. The introduction is simple enough for beginners to understand, but engaging enough that series veterans won't be bored out of their minds. As you progress through the game, you will start to solve tests with test 'elements'. These elements are things like lasers and cubes, which all interact with portals, and each other in unique ways. Each test chamber uses an element in a new way, to keep them from being stale. You travel through multiple parts of Aperture, all unique in their own way. You explore much more than just Aperture and it's factory, unlike the original. However, the campaign is very short (5-7) hours, and once you beat it, there is really no reason to replay it. The multiplayer is also fun, if you can find a friend to play it with. Playing with random people can be very unpredictable, but if you can find a friend, you'll have a good time. It adds more hours to the game, which is very welcome. The good news is once you beat the game, there are an infinite number of Community puzzles to try out.  Story: This game has a way deeper story than the original. It surpases it in practically all ways. The plot is longer, has more twists, and is more exciting. The characters are more engaging and humorous. Although there are only three of them, they are all memorable and unique. GLaDOS ends up taking a back seat to the two new characters however, in humor and in design. The characters and dialogue are one of the most memorable things about this game.  Level Editor: The in-game level editor (PTI Editor) will be where most of the community makes their puzzles. This editor will be where all beginner mappers will make their first puzzles. This editor is very easy to use, but is also quite simple. You can design simple chambers with basic elements, but to do anything unique and visually impressive, you need to use Hammer. Hammer is the powerful map-making tool that all of the best mappers use. It is also very confusing to any begginers. It will probably take a while to figure out how to make simple room, and it is way more complicated to make lights or doors or cube droppers. I speak from experience, as a wanna-be-mapper who was tired of the lack of content in PTI. If you can master Hammer, you will be able to easily become a fan-favorite mapper. When it comes to other people's maps though, you will be hard pressed to find quality ones. There is a good amount in top-rated of all time, but once you have done a lot of those, you will find that 95% of the maps are incredibly easy, PTI maps, or just plain impossible.   Pro/Con Summary (For those who don't want to read):  Pros: Hilarious dialogue Fun multiplayer One of a kind experience Infinite amount of community chambers to play Includes Hammer editor, in which you can make incredibly detailed and amazing puzzles Great progression of test elements, never gets stale Difficulty curve is not too steep or slow Good visual diversity considering the setting  Cons: Not much replay value A very short experience It can be hard to find quality community puzzles The PTI editor is simple, but lacking in content, while hammer allows you to make anything, while being complex. espeically for beginners

Portal 2….what can I say about you that will truly do you justice. To say that as a sequel Portal 2 is great (and by that I mean really great; one of the best follow ups in gaming history in my humble opinion) is the least of it. As a platformer/puzzle game, as a sequel, but simply as a game, Portal 2 is ‘all across the board’ a phenomenal achievement!   It’s easily twice as long as Portal and with more humor to go with that extra length. Co-op missions have also been added for additional gameplay and there is now an even crazier use of physics-based puzzle solving elements thrown into the mix, most notably with the addition of liquids that allow you/other objects to bounce (blue liquid), move faster (orange liquid) and create portals on surfaces you normally couldn’t utilize for that purpose (white liquid) – not gonna go into specifics on that or when that even factors into the game’s campaign but for certain Portal 2 is a wild ride fraught with wacky antics, danger, intrigue and….umm….potatoes (yeah, not gonna go into that either and spoil anything for ya! You’ll just have to find out on your own).   To sum up my thoughts: Portal 2……..I love you!!!!

This is my favourite game of all time. I just love this game so much; it really improved on the original portal in every way and is definitely one of the best sequels ever.  The graphics are good but what is great are the stunning varied environments that the game takes place in. The different settings are really dynamic and are incredibly interesting.  The gameplay is still amazing. there are new lots of new gameplay elements (such as the various gels) that increase the complexity of puzzles, which still remain challenging yet never in a frustrating way. Level designs are great and are just so fun.   The best thing though about this game is the depth of the outstanding story. All the characters are fascinating and of course hilarious.  There are so many unexpected twists in the story and Portal 2 truly has a brilliant start, middle and end - oh the end is so good. Many still complain about the length of the game which is about double the length of the first game, and while it can be completed in an afternoon I think the length is absolutely perfect. There's ton of content on the workshop anyway as well as co-op :P  So definitely buy this game, pretty much everyone has already anyway, i just wanted to say how much i love it. But of course play Portal 1 first, you dont have to but you'll be more engaged in this epic game.

I know how long this game has been out, but it's always fun to talk about!  The original Portal never felt like a full fledged game to me, more of a puzzle like Fez or Spelunky if brought to 3D (minus the colors and style). The gun was it's main selling point, and people were hooked by the mental exercise. Soon, the internet lit up with 'backstories' and theories on who the heck you played as and why GLaDOS is such a sadistic but lovable voice you could never get out of your head.  Portal 2 took the puzzling teleportation we liked and put it in a more story-driven adventurous setting. While you still (in a rough sense) navigate the similar rooms of the Aperture Science labs, there is an amazing amount of various places you'll be hopping around in. Not to mention the plethora of easter eggs You could sit around on Youtube for hours watching all of the videos on them!  All in all, the first Portal is a speedrunner's dream, not worth skipping if you haven't already played it. Portal 2 decided to take the addicting portal puzzles and put them in an adventurous setting with a better story (now on a Half-Life level) and unforgettable characters, some of which you will never even see their faces but recognize their dialouge or text anywhere on the internet.  Why are you reading this? You should've been playing this years ago!

I don't even know where to start with this game. I'm pretty sure by now, everyone who WANTED to play this game has either heard of it or played it already. Firstly it looks amazing. The graphics look superb, especially for being made on a 9 year old engine, it is truly astonishing. Secondly, gameplay. I've played this game, many, MANY, times over, and I'm still not sick of the gameplay elements. It's that good. Honeslty, as long as I have a PC, I will be replaying this game. Leading onto replayability. Portal 2 has lots. Ever since the Perpetual Cooperative Testing Initiative, and the addition of the Steam Workshop, there has never been so many reason to go back and play Portal 2, whether it be playing top rated chambers from the workshop, or discovering how socialable you are in cooperative. This game will become a classic, in generations to come. I just wish that Valve would make another masterpiece like it. It is one of the best games I have ever played. And unlike the Cake, that is no lie my fellow gamers.

Pretty much Valve's last great original game (and being a sequel that's really saying something), from back when they used to actually make games.  A brief Portal history for those interested:  2007: Original Portal, mixed in the Orange Box with the big-boys. Turns out to be a great surprise!  2008: Left 4 Dead. No Half-Life 2 Episode 3. OK, take an extra year to make it even better.  2009: Left 4 Dead 2. WHAT, ALREADY?! Instead of Half-Life 2 Episode 3. Fine, take another year.  2010: Alien Swarm. Really?? Still instead of Half-Life 2 Episode 3. Well at least it was free and somewhat fun (if can stand that view style).  2011: Portal 2. Awesome!!! But Half-Life 2 Episode 3? Nah, keep expanding Team Fortress 2 like mad instead.  2012: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Because I guess it was time to overhaul that instead of making Half-Life 2 Episode 3.  2013: DOTA 2. Uh, thanks? As in, no (unless you like that type of game).  2014-present: Ever-expanding Team Fortress 2, and some cool added Steam features (like broadcasting). I see. Nevermind then!

Have not got many hours on this on steam but have previously completed this on my xbox360. First of I would like to say that the basic mechanics are very good and are interesting because they have not really been explored before in any game. I will break this review down into several parts but it will not be too long.  Story- you may think a puzzle game like this may not have a good story but its better than good. Its easy to understand but has enough twists and turns to make this story engaging and interesting. It is also full of jokes that are quite subtle and some not so subtle. My favourite character was wheatly (played by steven merchant) as he was funny and kind of adorable in parts. But Glad0s was also halarious and intreging as she occasionally gives you clues about your parents.  Gameplay- It gives you very little to play with at the outset but as the game pushes forward it gets a lot harder and gives you more means to complete the chambers. It gives you a new mechanic, lets you master it and then introduces you to more and this repeats throughout the game to keep portal from getting stale.  Graphics- Runs on the source engine (sorry if I am wrong) which is what most if not all of valves games use. The graphics are very simple but timeless as the is never much colour in most of the game in this bleak, torn apart testing facility. Portal 2 will run on most computers and runs on my laptop which runs games like complete crap.  Extra- There is little to no lore in the portal universe at the moment but they still hav loads of good easter eggs like singing turrets and the lab rat location which are really eerie and creepy. I love the music for portal and have bought the soundtrack for portal and portal 2. This is my favourite valve game along with left 4 dead 2 and I would recomend it to pretty much anyone. R.I.P spelling.

As I mentioned in my Portal review Portal is the most fun you can have with your PC. Now we have a sequal that's more polished, longer, expands on the cannon of the game, new testing elements, a two player co-op campaign, and a level editor which lets you play fan made puzzles. There was nothing in that sentence I didn't like. From my personal experience the platforming and portal aiming was not quite as crisp and clean as in the original but that's the worst criticism I can think for it. And who knows? With such a large marketing push and glowing reviews (critics and users alike) all over the net, I honestly don't need to say anything you've heard a dozen times over already.  However, since its initial release there was a map editor released, and just recently Valve added co-op support for that map editor. So there is now, potentially, an infinite number of co-op maps for you and a friend to play. 'Continue testing,' says GLaDOS.  I originally played it on the X-box 360, but picked it up on Steam again because of the new player-generated content, and there are some pretty good puzzles out there.  Thanks to Richard for sending me a -75% coupon for this title, btw. (A lot of people have those floating in their steam Inventory, so ask around if you want to purchase this game.)

Now before you start yelling at me for my little playtime or my not doing the story or whatever I just want to say I also have portal 2 on my ps3. And I have gotten CRAZY far in it! So I'll base this reviw off of my expiriance...experiance...experence? I dunno. Anyways, Portal 2 is an amazing game. It has interesting lore [spiler](such as the neurotoxin flood and carolines death)[/spoiler] that I have spent hours researching. The gameplay is also wonderful (wonderfull?) the tests are well built and challenging. There are also plenty of amazing easter eggs such as the ratt man dens. The graphics are also amazing. The game looks so real that if I wasn't controlling it (and if everythign in it wasn't so impossible) I would easily mistaken it for a real video or something. I also like the overgwon plants and panels trying to put themselves together. Overall portal 2 is an amazing game and I would reccomend it to anyone who wants to challenge themselves.

Oh my lord. What an EPIC story.  You start as a test subject. You wake up in a house-like test chamber, and you start solving puzzles with your shinyyyy... portal gun. As the time goes on, the master of the house, Glados (?) wants to kill you, and you are helped by a little robot called Wheatley. When you finally make it to Glados so you can put Wheatley in charge and escape, something bad happens...  You continue literally from the bottom and make your way to Wheatley. You get to discover some of the history of the whole place, while solving a brain-scratching puzzles.  As I said, an EPIC story with EPIC sounds and musics, but I think that isn't enough to describe the whole EPICness. You really should test this game out, but here's a tip: don't give up, if the chambers feel hard ;). I spent a lot of time in them, but when you finally make it through, I can say, it was way more than worth it.  I don't remember much about the first Portal so I can not recommend to play it first, but I highly recommend you to play this one.  Thank you for you time.  PS: This game also doesn't require that much from a PC. I mean, my PC is built from pretty old components (Intel Core 2 Duo, GTX 650), and it's stuck at 60 FPS.

While singleplayer is challenging, I'll admit that co-op is slightly more challenging in a fun way. I've beat this game multiple times, and hasn't gotten any easier. It might be my crappy memory, and it might be my inability to actually be good at video games; either way, it's still fun in that makes-you-wanna-rip-all-your-hair-out way when you can't complete a chamber. The first time I played this game, it felt like I was falling in a dark pit, surrounded by pitch black nothingness. Second time, it got unnoticably brigther, but brighter still.  Then there's co-op. After my brother beat the game about 5 hours before me, he suggested we play co-op. Then he went to our grandparents house, and my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ self couldn't figure out how to wave so that stalled us from playing. But when I finally did figure out how to, we were then caught in other problems. Couldn't get out of the chamber. Thankfully, my idea came to the rescue! I felt so intelligent when I was able to get us out of that infuriating chamber with that one little dumb idea I had.  Really, the most infuriating part of this game is when your hands are starting to sweat or your fingers accidentally slip and you go whoosh! into the water, to your death. I can hear GLaDOS and her monotone voice as I type, mocking each little thing I do, or her arrogant voice during her little chats in the elevator ride or while you're sprinting down a hallway or something.  I rate this game an overall 8/10. HIGHLY recommended, completely worth every cent. Well, like 5 cents less, but still. It's a freakin' good game!

PROS; -Puzzles aren't too easy nor difficult -Controls are easy to learn -No cryptic thinking to exploit the games mechanics in order to pass levels -Campaign length is decent, fun and replayable -Characters add interesting moments at just the right times -Game runs very nice and smoothly on low power/budget hardware -Extra in-game features such as gel add an extra layer of depth to puzzles -Time trial modes  CONS: -Multiplayer can be frustrating when there's lack of co-operation -Some characters may become irritating if not in the mood to deal with dialogue -No multiple ways of solving the same puzzles -Loading screens may sometimes take a while depending on Co-op partner -Some puzzles may lead you to be stuck for a while without looking for guides/help  Overall, I give the game an 8/10. Pros:  In depth, challenging gameplay. Labyrinth style test chambers test your logic problem solving skills.  Smooth gameplay, well put together and thought out.  Great multiplayer.  Unique ideas and concepts make for great gaming experience.  The map editor released allows players to create their own test chambers, as well as play and rate other Portal 2 fans' test chambers,making the game just that bit more enjoyable than it already was.  Cons:  Storyline is short and there isn't much replayable content in my opinion, this however is aided to some extent by the recent D.L.C which provides challenges and the like.  Bottom line:   Portal 2 is a very unique game, it provides something different, which in itself is a reason to buy it. So many game designers poorly re-invent the same themes and ideas year after year but to see something unique coupled with gliding graphics and an interesting storyline makes Portal 2 a great addition to your gaming library. A game with a great story that follows on from Portal 1, the sinister GLaDOS will have you sliding, jumping and using portals through all sorts of things to get past each task. As you play you will get cheeky remarks from GLaDOS and even silly writings on the wall that will make you smile. but it doesn’t end here; you have the ability to play as two little test robots with any friend you like (even if they play on the PlayStation you can team up with them). This will lead to a few extra hours of brain teasing fun as you discuss with your friend how to pass each obstacle.  Cons: Frustration for the simple, On the short side.  Pros: Hilarious writing, voice acting, Fun cooperative mode, Terrific writing and voice acting adds two new memorable personalities to the Portal cast. New environmental elements including hard light bridges and super ability gels create fresh space-time-bending twists, Great ping system to communicate with friends.  Overall I highly recommend this game to anyone who wishes to play, even if you don't want to do story mode hitting up co-op is still worth it.

Valve added a remarkable amount of fun new mechanics, but at the same time shifted the focus towards more story, rendering Portal 2 more straightforward and somewhat easier. While I loved the subtle humor and lonely atmosphere of the first game, I laughed out loud many more times at the second one. Valve's witty writing is just something I utterly enjoy. Gameplay-wise, despite the new mechanics, I think I still enjoyed Portal 1 more. The puzzles just were a bit more challenging (in a good way, not a frustrating one). In the end, Portal 2 is an incredible game and an experience that should not be missed. Oh, almost forgot about the co-op mode. PLAY IT!

I'm gonna try to do this without exaggerating... It's been almost 4 years since the launch of this game, and still I find it one of the best games today... Starting by the graphics, you could argue that they are very minimalist, but you know what? They work, they are very simple, and plane, and glitch less... Everything looks really pretty and the effects look really good, without trying too hard, also making it so from a far they don't look bad in a weaker computer... For the sound, dear lord the sound is amazing, it's so immersive and it feels right... I never have epic music when I'm in a quiet part when i'm solving a puzzle, and accordingly I never have silence in an epic part... But the quietness while solving the puzzles makes it so you can really enjoy how awesome all the sound effects are... When Portal was released, it was a wonderous title that showed us what it meant to think in portals (and that the cake is a lie). Is it possible for a game to be any better than Portal 2? Of course. Anything is possible while Nintendo still makes Zelda games; but if we all pretend that series doesn't exist: This is as good as it gets.   Portal 2 represents all that can be great in a video game. It's legitimately funny, brilliantly scripted, features impeccable voice acting, its gameplay mechanics are rock solid, it presents a fair challenge, and its replay value is about as close to infinite as I think a game can be (especially with the addition of the Perpetual Testing Initiative); but the most important trait of all is that Portal 2 is just incredibly fun-- and isn't that what's most important?   (In the interest of full disclosure: The 17.7 hours of play time at the time of this writing is only the amount I've played this game on Steam. I have had much more experience with the game on Xbox 360 like the terrible console peasant I am.)

First game I got on Steam, and I've not reviewed it yet. It's time I did. This is not a game. This is a work of art. Valve struck gold in 2007 with the release of The Orange Box, a package which indluded games like Half-Life 2 and the episodes, Team Fortress 2, and Portal. Portal was an experiment, and yet was acclaimed as one of the most original games of that year. Developement of a sequel began right away. Usually it's difficult to live up to such an incredible game in a sequel, but Portal 2 showed just how good a sequel can be. An extended story, more characters and character development, and the almighty GLaDOS. The puzzles were increased in quantity, quality, and length. The gameplay was suberb, the story was even better, managing to not take itself seriously in some parts, and still managing to be serious where it needs to be. All in all, 9.9/10. Why 9.9? Because I never rate a game 10.

Strange as it may seem to start a five-star review on a note of concern, I worry about Valve. It's not that I think the developer has put a foot wrong so far, or that its latest release won't meet the impossibly high expectations of its audience. On the whole, the titles that Valve has produced have been critically lauded and have sold very respectably.  But if the history of art and entertainment has taught us one thing it is this: if you habitually make genius look easy, audiences and critics will round on you if you stumble, even more viciously than they would have done if your track record was of a mediocre quality. Valve's winning streak has to get snapped at some point, doesn't it? And if it does, the knives will be out in force.  Well, thankfully, Portal 2 isn't the game that's going to cause this, which is remarkable when you consider it's arguably the sequel of 2011 with the toughest act to follow. The first Portal, released in 2007 as part of the Orange Box, was a short, ingenious puzzler wrapped up in first-person-shooter mechanics, underpinned by a darkly comic story about scientific research taken to dangerous extremes. The game seemed like lightning in a bottle and a sequel sounded unnecessary. Still, Valve has managed to go one better than what its team created before, and then built on its impressive foundations.  Portal 2 kicks off with player waking up in the Aperture Laboratories, the human behaviour research facility from the first game, and finding out very quickly that things have gone haywire. Aperture is a wreck: without GlaDOS – Portal 1's female AI antagonist – to run things, the facility is in an advanced state of disrepair. Walls are crumbling, test chambers malfunction and every room the player moves through is riddled with smashed windows, natural overgrowth and broken machinery. In the opening stages of the game, players are introduced to Wheatly, a stammering, motor-mouthed droid voiced by Stephen Merchant, and reacquainted with the Portal Gun, which creates interconnecting portals capable of bending distances, and physics, in their environment.    They're also soon reunited with GlaDOS, who takes umbrage at their presence and decides that a new round of potentially lethal tests is in order.  While the set-up will sound incredibly familiar to Portal veterans, Portal 2 is hardly a retread of the first game. Yes, using the Portal Gun to navigate one's way through every new environment is the core premise of the game – and cubes, gun turrets, floating platforms and pressure pads all make a return. But Valve has added some mind-bending mechanics and tools to the mix.  As the player advances through the Apeture Labs they're introduced to new items that the research facility has created to exercise their grey matter and potentially kill them off. There are Hard Light Bridges, which can create walkways or block off the sensors of lasers and gun turrets. There are Aerial Faith Plates, which fling the player through the air. There's Propulsion Gel, which allows them to zoom across the floor, building momentum for jumps and portal leaps. Puddles of Repulsion Gel can create areas the player can bounce on– and the higher the ledge they drop from, the higher they'll fly through the air. White Gel can be sprayed on to surfaces to make them Portal Gun-friendly. Excursion funnels are blue tubes of anti-gravity, which gently transport the player from one end of the map to the other, and they too can be redirected and repositioned with the Portal Gun. Each new item is introduced gently, to let the player become familiar with its capabilities, and then Valve starts ramping up the difficulty.  The puzzle rooms are incredibly well designed in that there's no hard and fast rule with the game's difficulty curve. Once the tutorials are out of the way, it's down to every individual player's desire to break the code on each environment, which allows them to move from the entrance to the exit. Even if one player finds the solution to one particular room obvious, this doesn't mean that everyone else will, and some puzzles may take up to hour to solve. All the while GlaDOS pours scorn over the player's efforts, with a stream of insults that are petty, vindictive and immature – made more hilarious by her robotic, sing-song voice.  The humour in Portal 2 is another trump card in the game's well-paced, engrossing and unsettling story. Without giving too much of the game's plot away, the player will find Portal 2 funny throughout, but also faintly spinechilling. GlaDOS and Wheatly are by turns funny and monstrous and the Aperture Labs take on an increasingly oppressive atmosphere as the player ventures deeper into the facility, learning more about its origins. Meanwhile, the unseen character from the first Portal is still lurking behind the scenes, scrawling paranoid messages and horrific cartoons on the walls.  The game's main campaign is longer than in Portal 1, and arguably better too. Once that's over and done with, however, players can return to Aperture in the multiplayer. This mode is a standalone story starring two cute droids, Atlas and Peabody, who are sent testing by GlaDOS, and the series of puzzles they have to navigate depends on them working successfully as a team. While it may sound strange that a game offering such a successful solitary experience as Portal should include such a mode, it's actually delightful fun. Once again, the puzzles are well-balanced and brilliantly constructed and, GlaDOS has a new collection of insults.  Valve has created a masterpiece in Portal 2. The depth of content, the mind-bending mechanics and fantastic experience are almost certain to satisfy ardent fans of the first game; and to all newcomers to the series, it's as simple as this: prepare to have your mind blown. Over and over again.

Well, this was quite a drastic change from the first Portal. Not in a bad way like Hitman: Absolution (which i reviewed in a bit too much of detail). This could be one of the best sequels for a game, I've played, though it really didn't start as a serious project and since bloomed into something that's pretty damn great.   If you're not familiar, this was really just a lone physics game that valve aquired and then turned into Portal. So where to go from a shot game about puzzles with physics? Start with: new puzzles (obviously), also make a well made story with atmosphere and humor the game was originally known for, include a mysterious deeper lore for previous fans, add new ways to solve puzzles, have friends co-op on a seperate part of the game with even more puzzles, then finaly as Cave Johnson would probably add 'Market the crap out of it'.    So i am here to say they did it all, and they did it right. It's hard for me to say anything bad, not even sure there is anything inherently bad about this game. Maybe how mainsteam the game has become? Not really. Lack of puzzels after game? No they fixed that. Maybe the lack of answers from the lore? Hopefully in time it will all be answered. But overall in gameplay, visuals, and story, this one is a keeper.

Then rub ya wubba butt and you actually feel it! But its a game so you cant do that but IF portal guns and portals existed IRL, then that would be awsome. :D Totally reccomend this game for anyone that likes puzzles and science-ish stuff.. 9/10

Words cannot describe the sheer awesomeness of this game, both in single-player mode and in the workshop mode (where you create your own test chambers, and play other players' test chambers). In single-player, the storyline, controls, dialogue, characterization, music, atmosphere, and flow of the game blend together perfectly; It cannot be any better than it already is. Co-op mode's great as well, but it has a serious, recurring error, where the game will suddenly disconnect you, and player you're with, for no apparent reason. Workshop mode is tricky at first, as figuring out the controls, and what kinds of test chambers people enjoy, can be frustrating, but once you figure out both of those issues, everything else goes smoothly. Overall, 9 out of 10.

Not much can be said on my part that hasn't already been expressed by others in ther reviews of Portal 2, but I feel that this game is the definitive adventure game sequel to come from Valve. Yes, I've played Half-Life 2. No, I didn't enjoy that. 1. Gameplay: The core idea that Portal 2 holds is very simple. Shoot two portals, walk through one, you walk out the other. But as you progress through the game it begins to add many layers to this formula which make it into the complex, semi-difficult puzzle adventure it's known as. 2. Story: While this may be somewhat odd to pick up without having played the first game, Portal 2 is definitely accessible to those new to the franchise's short plot line, and certainly welcomes them. The few characters you meet along the way all have very distinct personalities, and just ooze charm with some of their memorable quotes throughout. The main story line (SPOILER ALERT) is a sort of escape story at the start, just trying to find a way out of the clutches of GladOS, but after being betrayed by Wheatley, the story takes a turn for the more complex, giving inciteful backstory on Aperture Science and GladOS herself, makin this somewhat more entertaining for those who played through the first as well. In the end, it's got a good solid story, and the ending is amazing. Also, finding all the Rattman dens is worth your time if you're not planning to rush the game. 3. Control: The physics and controls in this game are some of the tightest I've seen in a 3D puzzle physics game, and that's absolutely necessary, because without pinpoint precision, you're not going to complete the tests, now are you? 4. Audiovisuals: The soundtrack for this game holds a mysterious feel throughout as ou explore the abandoned halls of Old and New Aperture, and although it never truly holds a forefront position in the game's atmosphere except in a few more intense situations, it holds it's own. The graphics are stellar and make for a nice attention to detail. This looks good for a game from 2011. Overall, Portal 2 is one of Valve's most solid titles and is certainly worth your time, more so than Half Life 2. And if you're seekin humor, I will say that without a doubt this game managed to make me chuckle a few times.

A good game. Some of its puzzles are capable of giving one a headache, however they are all doable for an averagely intelligent player. Despite the fact that the game is focused on solving physics-based puzzles only, it does not get boring. Almost every new test chamber introduces new elements, which requires the player to try different approaches. A nice feature is the multi-player co-op mode which allows the player to be tested together with a friend. The game looks very well-made and detailed. It is hard to find any bugs in it, which I always like to do out of curiosity. The plot is definitely a bit more complex than in the game's prequel, and it is also often filled with humor, which is another plus. All in all, I believe it is one of the best games made by Valve so far, and I would certainly recommend it to everyone; except obviously children for whom it would be definitely too difficult.

Portal 1 and 2, taken as a single unit, is possibly the best gaming experience i've ever had. The last time i called a game 'my favorite game ever' was Another World/Out of This World, and that was a long time ago. Portal, and especially Portal 2, is written, designed, and scored with such excellence and ingenuity. Storytelling, drama, humor, and fantastic music, as well as true playability for gamers of all types, are the strengths i see here. i played through Portal 1 twice, and will soon play through Portal 2 a second time, just for the fun of it (and the commentary). i highly recommend this game. Even if you're not a hard core gamer (i'm not), you should play the Portal series. i experienced only moderate frustration on a couple levels/puzzles, but never once had to look for hints or cheats. i also experienced virtually zero bugs or crashes (i can't remember any crashes, though i might have forgotten something due to just totally loving this game). So again... Play Portal!

It also offers nice surprises much like Glados' revival and plot twists like.... well, I won't spoil just what exactly happens :P  My overall opinion of the game is highly positive. Portal 2 is an amazing sequal next to the first groundbraking game of the Portal series. Portal 2 will keep you busy for hours on in with the endless amount of levels which constantly test one's skills of deduction and problem solving. The campaign mode fun but yet daunting sets you in a futuristic maze of technology. If that doesn't entertain you the constant back and forth commentary between everyone's favorite AI GLaDOS and of course Wheatley will give you a good laugh or two. Portal 2 also now offers a Co-Op mode which lets multiple players engage in solving the most difficult levels while having a buddy at your side. The game also has a lot of extra mods and user created levels off of the Steam Workshop for all of you willing to constantly test new levels. On top of Portal 2 being an amazing sequel to the series, it's a fairly inexpensive game for the amount of content you get out of the game. Portal 2 is just one of those games you can pick up at anytime, fun for everyone.
love the game

Everyone knows this game is good. It has received dozens of accolades and since its release, still has a strong fanbase as attested to by the influx of community made maps. So instead of further praising this masterpiece, I'd prefer to explain some of its drawbacks.  Expect a lot of loading times. That is by far, my biggest gripe. After every few puzzles, you will be greeted with a loading screen. In some instances where the puzzles are extremely easy, you'll begin to feel as if you've spent more times on loading screens than actually playing.  Unfortunately (or fortunately), that is the only negative thing I have to say about this game. Face it: the puzzles are cleverly crafted, the dialogue is witty and hilarious. The campaigns, both single player and cooperative are decent in length. There really is nothing to dislike... well maybe hats. If you don't like hats, then you won't be too happy to see them online.  Grade: A

Portal 2 is a worthy sequel to the first game. Although it does a poorer job of mixing story with gameplay, both the former and the latter are better than they were in the first game; Portal 2 sports more characters, although our old friend GLaDOS makes a return as a main character and is still the most likable in the game. There's a host of new gameplay mechanics, such as propulsion, repulsion, and conversion gel, all substances that either propel the player into the air, speed up the player's movements, or makes a surface portal-a-ble. This game also provides to us what I consider to be one of the best endings in gaming history, at least for the single player campaign, which leads me to my next point: there's more than one campaign! Portal 2's cooperative campaign thrusts you and another player into the position of Atlas and P-Body, GLaDOS' personal testing androids. You'll solve very complex test chambers with a friend, and it proves to be a true meeting of the minds as you combine your intellect to complete these puzzles and achieve a strong sense of satisfaction afterwards. Aside from this, it is also worth noting that thanks to the Perpetual Testing Initiative, a free map editor fully equipped with workshop support, this game's replay ability is now as infinite as its community's imagination.  TL;DR  Better than the original, definitely worth your money.

Jumping off of the success of Portal 1, Portal 2 here actually prides it self on what amounts to an absolutely FANTASTIC story. As goes with 1, pretty much 70% of it is tutorial, although it isn't as seamless as it was and you can actually feel it more this time around since the first tests each seem short at first and not really a new test to be solved, but actually trying to get you to learn the new mechanic. Where you had a free and open area to try out different ways to solve a challenge, now you have a certain number of pieces to a puzzle that you try and find the right order they go in. If you want straight puzzles and lots of 'em, they're in the multiplayer, which is also AMAZING, and with its own separate storyline. The new elements all add so much more to the game and ways any test can be completed. I would have gladly paid double for this game with how immersive the story is and of course the absolute flawlessness of the gameplay, not to mention it is purely fun.

A mellow review, free of criticism and rants...  I've missed out on such a classic game. Ran the co-op mode with my close friends few days ago, and finished the single player just yesterday.  Single player: The single player's story is rather entertaining. It's a puzzle game and it keeps up a rather smooth story and keeps away from making the puzzle ridiculously hard so to move on with the story. Commical and thrilling if I were to describe living the moments of Portal 2. Despite not having a partner like in co-op, the characters do a great job in entertaining you and encouraging you through the puzzles. Even the storyline in the single player mode can become a facinating discussion topic with your friends. The rules to the puzzle-solving are really simple. White space, make a portal, go through it. There are the blue, orange, white paint with automated turrets trying to kill you and everything but they easily become part of the game.  Co-op The mascots of Portal 2 (in my opinion), P-body and Atlus, are both very adorable touch to a rather unique co-op puzzle game. It's a very different experience from the single player, which avoids making the gameplay feel plainly repetitive. Lots of fun in 10% of the time trying to actually solve the puzzle while other 90% is dwelling in the temptation of wanting to kill each other. Getting achievements in this silliness adds more laugh to the short 8 hours journey. (Maybe more, depends on how good you are at killing your partner.)  Post Game There are other challenges you can do, or other puzzles available in Steam workshop. You won't end up playing as often as you do the first few hours after beating the game. Is it worth the money? Yes, and even more worth it when it's on sale.  It seems like you can get active in the Portal community, which should be fairly easy to do, and explore more loads of fun Portal 2 has stored within. Just grab some friends to be part of it with you...   I got other games I want to play at the moment, but I feel that I'd definitely come back for more of this. Fantastic puzzle game! Enjoyable! Graphically nice looking, and amazing character animation and voice acting!

After the first Portal came out, no one was REALLY expecting a sequel. Don't get me wrong, It was a great game. But, it was extremely short, and I mean EXTREMELY short, and the narrative kind of came full circle by the end. You test, you test, you find out Glados is evil, almost die, kill her, THE END. So really, when the sequel was announced, everyone was excited but still cautious, as no one really knew what it was going to be about. What came out however, is holding a place in my top ten video games of all time, Portal 2 is that good. The story should take over 10 hours, and below 15 hours to complete, smashing Portal 1's 3 hour journey. The length does depend, however, on how good you are at thinking with portals. But every second of this game is awesome. Glados makes a more than welcome return, a new character called Wheatley is introduced, who is hilarious. The voice acting is spectacular, the visuals are crisp and clean, the story is deep and envoking (yes, in a game where you go around shooting portals, the story is deep and envoking) and if that isn't enough, there is an awesome co-op side game you can play with friends, which is actually just as good as the main story. The level designs are awesome, and it is always fun with friends. The thing Portal 2 really succeeds at, however, is making it difficult enough but not making it seem unfair, and not making you want to stop playing. Portal 2 is a brilliant game, and.... Portal 3? Valve? Play Portal 2 if you haven't already.
It was good

This game... THIS GAME. This has got to be one of the best games on Steam. It fills in the gaps of the story from the original Portal, and delivers a campaign that will take you a good 30 hours or so to complete. The story is brilliantly written, and the puzzles are also well designed. The game is full of light-hearted humor, and although it might not be enough to make you laugh out loud, you'll definitely be enjoying the humorous voice-acting as you think to solve the difficult puzzles.  And then there's Co-Op mode. I personally like to call it 'Portal your partner into traps until they ragequit', but that's just me. The Co-Op mode can take a good eight hours or so to complete.  So the base game gives you almost 40 hours worth of enjoyment, and let me tell you that going back and playing the singleplayer campaign isn't even that uncommon, since you can sometimes find things you missed the first time around.  The game also includes a decent map editor with Steam Workshop support, so you will never run out of things to play.

Although I already owned and played Portal 2 on Xbox 360, I also got it on sale on Steam one day because I love the game so much. Portal 2, like the first game, is a puzzle/problem solving game where you need to go through different 'test' chambers, using only what is around you and your portal gun. The storyline in Portal 2 is a lot more complex and longer than it's predecessor, though, and your objective is to escape the testing facility. There is also a lot more dialogue in this game, although your own character never actually says anything. Along the way, there will be many comical moments as well, making the game very enjoyable.  I don't want to spoil anything so I will stop myself, but if you like the original Portal game, or even if you have never played it before, I am sure you will definitely love this game.

*English Version below. Keep in mind, that I'm not that good at speaking English, but I hope it's okay for you.*  Portal 2... was soll ich dazu noch groß sagen?  Ein Juwel von einem Spiel, das finden auch die anderen momentan 134,617 Leute, die Portal 2 empfehlen.  Nicht nur, dass die Idee der Portal-Gun wunderbar frisch und unausgenutzt ist, es spielt sich auch klasse. Die Rätsel sind komplex und bringen die grauen Zellen ordentlich zum Rauchen. Der Coop-Modus motiviert und macht mit einem Freund über Voice Chat extrem viel Spaß! Gesamt kann man etwa 25 Stunden mit dem Spiel verbringen, wenn man Story und Coop-Modus einmal durchspielt. Es gibt mittlerweile aber auch noch einige andere Features, wie etwa den Challenge-Modus, der nochmal für einige Stunden mehr Spielzeit sorgt. Die Geschichte ist schlichtweg genial: GLaDOS sorgt für hunderte lustige Momente, und der Humor trifft genau ins Schwarze. Was nicht heißen soll, dass es schwarzer Humor ist... keineswegs, der Humor ist gleichzeitig speziell als auch für jedermann und ich kenne niemanden, der nicht bei den zahlreichen Sprüchen und Anekdoten von GLaDOS nicht zumindest schmunzeln muss. Auch sonst ist die Geschichte toll, und das Ende toppt an Humor alles, was ich bis her gesehen habe... SPAAAAACE *-* Der traditionelle Song am Ende fand ich zwar gut, aber an den genialen Song aus Portal 1 kam er nicht ran. Sowohl deutsche als auch englische Sprachausgabe sind absolut top.  Was bleibt noch zu erwähnen... KAUFEN!!! :) Egal welche Genres du normalerweise spielst, egal welches Setting du bevorzugst, du wirst Portal 2 und insbesondere GLaDOS mögen, lieben und hassen lernen. ;)  **********  Portal 2... nothing more to say.  A wonderful game, that's not only what I'm thinking, but also the other 134,617 people, who recommend Portal 2 at the moment. Not only the idea of the Portal-Gun is new and unexploited, but also the gameplay is excellent. The puzzles are very complex - especially later on in the game - and your brain will have a hard time solving them. The Coop-mode is motivating and extremely fun when played with a friend using voice chat, teamspeak or skype. The game takes around 25 hours of your time when you want to finish the campaign and the Coop-mode. Nowadays there are also some more features like the mod-suport or the challenge-mode, which make you spend even more time in the game. The story is simply brilliant: GLaDOS makes you laugh nearly every second and the humor is again very cool. It's both humor for everyone but also black humor sometimes. I know nobody who doesn't at least smile while playing Portal 2. And then there's the ending. Phenomenal! It's so much fun... SPAAAAACE *-* The ending song is pretty good again, but I liked the one from Portal 1 a bit more. Since English is not my mother tongue I played the game in both German and English. Both are pretty good voice acted.  Nothing more to say except, BUY IT!!! :) No matter what genre you prefere, you'll get to know, love and hate the game and especially GLaDOS. ;)
If you do not have this game, you're missing out on excellent humor and great new puzzles. :D

Portal 2 is one of those games that you come across once in a lifetime. It comes after Portal, which revolutionized the concept of running through portals to solve puzzles, which is an ingenious new take on gaming itself. I have never had a true favorite game until I played Portal 2. I admit I wasn’t so addicted to it at first, playing it off and on over the span of a few weeks. I honestly don’t know what grabbed me, but as soon as I blinked, I was addicted.   Now, I hear all the negativity that can come with saying that one thinks Portal 2 is better than Portal, but honestly, if I’d played Portal first, I wouldn’t have bought as much merchandise as I have sitting in my house right now. It’s the kind of game that makes you WANT to contribute as much of your money to as possible, because it’s that great of a game.   I love gifting this game to other Steam players (as well as Portal, but I particularly love giving out this game twice as much). It’s not a game many people should miss out on, and if you love puzzles and verbal abuse from an AI, this game is definitely something you should buy (even at full price).   GLaDOS is waiting. You monster.

Portal 2 is a ground breaking game that continues the rather lacking story from the first game. That said if the story doesn't interest you and you just want to solve more puzzles, go right ahead and solve some chambers made by other players. I know i've spent a good deal of time in the community chambers.   The characters are all funny and likable (even the evil ones) and although you only meet four people face to face (counting the co-op bots at the end) you learn the story of others through audio and rats nests. The puzzles are very well thought out and take time and thought to complete, and even then you almost never know all the solutions.   The co-op is at best frustrating. While a good concept, I felt that unless you are playing with a friend it's almost impossible. And even then it's very frustrating trying to get them to think like you. As self centered as that sounds, it's true; this game requires both players to think as one, and most friends don't.   All in all it's a good game. Fingers crossed for Portal 3.  PS: HALF LIFE 3 CONFIRMED!

Continuing where Portal left off, Portal 2 plunges you into a whole new (and some very old) Aperture Science Laboratories! New puzzles, new tech, new storylines, two-player mode and a map-making and sharing tool! This game is everything I'd ever wanted and more from the sequel. :)

As someone who has logged hundreds of hours on TF2 and Garry's Mod, I am no stranger to the first person perspective but I am newer to the puzzler aspect of Portal games. I played through the first installment and absolutely loved it. It was short, sweet, and reasonably challenging while having a great core mechanic and awesome sense of humor. Now, Portal 2 has built on it and has added more of the fun from Portal. The sense of humor is not as sardonic and dark as the first one but still pretty funny. The game itself is a bit dull at points but the physics engine is beyond amazing and the scenery is really crisp and engaging especially on my HD monitor. The game doesn't add too much new to the core mechanics which is a good thing because they have no need for a change. The story drags a bit but overall the few criticisms I have for it are far outweighed by the fact that it is still one of the few games I will play over and over again, once I beat it. Above all, play the first one before you even touch the second, the story will make much more sense and you will find better humor and tighter gameplay there. But again, I highly recommend Portal 2, it just has the unfortunate position of being the sequel to what has to be my favorite game of all time so, I still score it 94/100.
