Portal 2 is the successor to Portal, a game originaly released in The Oragnge Box, a package of games including Half Life 2, HL2 episode 1, and HL2 episode 2, but can now be purchased alone. Portal 2 improves on Portal in many ways, from adding new game mechanics to a deeper story with more charcters. You find yourself in an Aperture Science Relaxiation Vault, a little room resembeling a hotel room. As you wake up, you are told to do a series of simple tasks, and go back to sleep. The next time you wake up, Aperture Science is in ruins. It has been a very long time since you woke last, and you are waken by a little robot core named Wheatly. Aperture Science is about to explode, and Wheatly helps you work through to get out. You go though a series of tests, midway though you get the Aperture Science Hand Held Portal Device, which helps you solve the tests. You meet up with Wheatly, and go to GLaDOS's chainber, the robot in charge of the facility, and is now turned off. You accendatly turn her on, and she gives you the Aperture Science Hand Held Dual Portal Device, or the Portal Gun, which allows you to shoot two portals instead of one. You now go though a series of tests guided by her, and when you make it to her chainber, you defeat her by replacing her with Wheatly. But, when you give this power to Wheatly, he turns evil and traps you into a pit. You fall down a hole into Old Aperture, which was used in the 50's though 80's. You make your way through the test chainberes guided not by GLaDOS, but by Cave Johnson, the then CEO of Aperture Science. You make your way up into Wheatly's lair, where you defeat him. This game is Amazing, but you'll get the full experiance if you play Portal first, then move on to Portal 2.

Portal 2 is a fanstastic sequal to the small source project that was the original Portal. The game has inventive mechanics, an interesting lore, hilarious and unique charactors, and a great story. The game also supports Co-Op and community maps. While others may complain of the story length, I found it to be absolutly perfect. The puzzels strike the right difficulty in each level and, if the puzzels seem to easy, community maps are availble to wrap your brain around.  All around, Portal 2 is a great game with darkly comedic charctors, inventive gameplay, and excellent puzzels. This game is worth paying full price for, but I understand if players want to wait for it to go on sale before snagging it at a bargain price.
I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who has trouble with dry humor, creative puzzle solving or fun.

Portal 2 is a great game created by Valve. You are basically a guinea pig (test subject) who is a girl named chell. And in the previous game portal the machine that created these puzzels and tricked you and tried to kill you is named GLaDOS. You eventually kill her. Well in portal 2 you are still playing as the original character chell and was in a room where you would be picked for later testing. But a robot came alon named wheatley who comes along and helps you out and you come across GLaDOS turned. but of course wheatley does something stupid and you have to fight her again going through 19 puzzles. And when you defeat her wheatley is now in charge and GLaDOS's intelligence is now in a potatoe which you carry around with you because wheatley through you two down a hole. And as you travel through the underground you come across the first testing chambers and find a story that you will have to find out for yourself. But in these testing chambers your using gel. The blue allows you to jump higher, the orange to move faster and the white allows you to create portals where it has touched. (Oh and when you get to chapter 6 you will find a achievement realating to half life. BORIALIS). And at the end you send wheatley into space and your sent out into a wheat field. I recomend this game to everyone. Now youre thinking with portals.

Portal and Portal 2 are amazing games! They should be a must-play for all gamers. It introduces lots of science in a video game which fits well with its perfect storyline. When I say 'science in a video game,' I mean literally use some scientific equations. I cannot confirm this, but I remember hearing somewhere that they used a real life equation for velocity in the games objects. The puzzles get harder to solve as you go along, and at some point, you may not even be able to solve it yourself! Grab a buddy and go through these puzzles (if you dont have a buddy, Wikipedia is there...). Its mysterious background fits well for this, and why (as well as fits in another VALVe title...). The Portal franchise itself is fantastic and I still think it has the best storyline of any game ever! I first played this game in 2011, and I've played many Triple A (AAA) titles. This game, right here, can single-handedly change your view on many good game stories, concepts, and maybe even (if you don't like shooter games) change your opinion on disliking some other games. I always, to this day, and always will, compare a games quality to Portal.  I give the Portal franchise a 10/10.

Portal, while a great game, was effectively a tech demo with a bit of plot tacked on. Portal 2, on the other hand, is the exact opposite: Not much more is added that hasn't been seen in games before, but you're playing for the plot this time, which despite being quite basic manages to be gripping. The dialogue is flawless, with the voice actors perfectly cast, and the humour is spot on, with the dark humour of the original provided in spades.  That being said, some of the challenge of the original game is sadly missing, with much of the   Old Aperture   tests being bland, with a large number simply being a case of finding the patch of slightly less grey wall and then deciding whether you need to spray gel on it or stand on it. The novelty of these gels wears off rather quickly, trampolines and patches which make you run faster didn't exactly make their debut here, and so you spend much of the   Old Aperture   section waiting for it to end.  However, it's well worth it when it does.   Wheatley's   chambers are possibly the best in the game, and the boss fight is a massive improvement on the slightly repetitive GlaDOS fight of the original, with not one element of it unmemorable. Well worth replaying as well, there's actually more dialogue for that scene than there is  time , so it's worth earning a few game overs.  Long story short, great game and an improvement over the original, however not worth playing if you plan to play with sound off or didn't like the original.

Apart for the short story and some little problems not worth mentioning, this game is perfect! With the originality, the unique story, the Coop mode and a joke every now and then, I'm safe to say this is my favorite game at the moment. I have honestly never played a game like this. The puzzles were challenging and fun to do. I also have to mention that they did a great job on balancing the puzzles and the story so it doesn't get repetitive.   Also there is a coop mode where you and your partner play with a different portal device, making the puzzles even more challenging. There is a handy pinging option, and a ping that counts down for when you have to do the same action simultaneously. This makes it very easy to tell your partner what to do.  Even if you have completed the entire story, and completed all maps in coop mode, you can still play or even make player made maps. These can also be solo or cooperative. Therefor there are plenty of maps to play after the story.  If you're not into common games (like shooters, MMO's etc.), then you should defenitely get Portal and/or Portal 2.

I love Portal 2. It's a great sequel to the original innovative puzzle FPS with amazing new features. I enjoy how they have kept comedy in the game, but also have a serious plot regarding Chell's continuing efforts to escape the mysterious Aperture Laboratories. Also, I love how now the Portal community is able to create test chambers and share their creations with the community, even though there can be a corrupted autosave glitch. Before you move on to a different game, you must check out the co-op Portal 2 campaign. It delivers a new, more challenging experience to the game that you can share with a friend (or a random person online), as long as you don't be a jerk to your partner. Overall, I recommend this game for everyone who enjoys playing a game that makes them think, or to people in it for the commedy, or the story (I recommend playing the first Portal to catch up on the story) for it is a truly unique game that offers a different FPS experience compared to other run and gun FPS. I rate this game a 9/10, for it is an amazing game, even though there are a few issues such as the corrupted autosave, or the one jerk co-op partner.

Ok, so the first Portal is amazing, right? Sadly, for me, the sequel doesn´t hold up to the first one, still a great game tho.  Don´t get me wrong, Co-Op is fun, gameplay is amazing, dialogue is fantastic, but the puzzles...  They start good, then they get better when they introduce gels and bridges, but sometimes you will find rooms that you have to be doing something PERFECTLY good or the answer isn´t as obvious as you think. I will admit, I noclipped some rooms of the last 2 stages because some of the puzzles were ridiculous and frustrating, and to be honest, they seem rushed. I really wonder what happened, in the other chapters the puzzles were great and had excellent difficulty, but damn, those last 2 chapters, along with the entirety of old Aperture are frustrating (The last 2 chapters more than old Aperture).  Also, I hate how there´s a loading screen for every single room. It really does ruin the flow and pacing of the game.  As I said, Co-Op is fun as hell. Grab a buddy, play locally, and one moment you´ll be celebrating, while other times you will want to kill eachother, it´s great.  And the fact that there´s a LOT of post-content made by users after completing the game (and there are people still doing levels!) is amazing.  So yeah, if you liked Portal and like puzzle games, go get it, it´s great  8/10

This game is pure fun. It's not a bad thing, but one of the things I miss about the first game in this one is how it actually wasn't focused so much on the fun, but on the lonelines. The Companion Cube made sense in the first game, since you were essentially all alone, with only GLaDOS talking to you and never out of the bounds of the test, until the very end. In this game, you have Wheatley, GLaDOS always taunting you, making her way more personal than in the first game so you actually have a connection, her hate towards you, Cave Johnson's recordings, and then GLaDOS again as an actual companion. It doesn't make this game bad, but it's a lot different than what I excpected of a Portal game. It's probably just nostalgia.  I can't honestly call this a classic, but I can say that it will be. Probably. Unless a global termonuclear war happens in the following years.

Gameplay: The Portal Gun is the keystone that makes playing the game so much fun. Great puzzles that vary in difficulty but never frustratingly complicated. It builds upon the great foundation of the original title 'Portal'. Multiplayer mode was a blast and I recommend playing with someone you know who finished single player.  Graphics: Just awesome. Really starts off with a bang in this department. The artists did very well adding little details everywhere you go. Many awe inspring moments throughout the game.  Sound: This game really shines in this department! The music fits the mood and environments incredibly well. The sound effects are iconic. The voice acting is superb.  Story: Great from beginning to end. Delves deep into the history of Aperture Science but leaves some room for mystery and intrigue. The protagonist doesn't speak but the writing for the other characters is so phenomenal it makes up for it. Wheatley and GLaDOS are two of the best characters in gaming.  Bottom-line: A Masterpiece! One of the greatest games ever made.  Score: 10/10

This is a really fun adventure.  Highlights are:  -The game is divided into multiple chapters (like acts in a play). Each has a story arc (with a bigger overall arc). -The writing is great which extends into awesome characters voiced really well (professional voice actors). -It doesn't take itself too seriously - its really fun. -The puzzles are good, and introduce new mechanics at a good rate so its not too boring. -the game worlds are really immersive - and contribute to the story. -The ending really uses the eurphoia that finishing the game gives you (won't spoil too much!).  It is not necessary to have played the first game, however it will make your experience better since you will understand the world, GLADOS (A main character), and the story (including the ending) a bit better.

Portal 2 is definitely a must buy. It is one of those games that hooks you in from the start until the very end and leaves that feeling of 'i want some more' when you're done with it.  STORY The story takes place after Portal 1 and is told pretty much alike: dubious, obscure, interpretative. You're constantly being manipulated by the characters in this game, and the few truths are to be found or concluded by yourself and/or outside of the test chambers, where you get to visit Aperture's offices and learn about it's creations and origins. Personally i love these kinds of storytelling because it opens so much space for discussion and secrets that it makes the game even more entertaining.  GAMEPLAY It's basically a puzzle game that consists into figuring out the portals physics and how to interact with the enviroment around you and with other gizmos such as turrets, crates, the infamous Companion Cube, gels and so on.Some of them are quite hard and challenging. It's a better version of Portal on this aspect, and if you have played it and liked it, you're bound to enjoy Portal 2's gameplay as well.  CHARACTERS I felt that creating this topic was important because the main antagonists in this game are AMAZING. Ellen McLain did and astonishing job on voicing GLaDOS. She annoys you, manipulates you, makes you angry, is ironic and has one of the smartest dialogue to be seen in videogame history. Definitely my personal favorite villain. And there's also Wheatley, a british-ish robot core that (SPOILER!) starts as a friendly guy but betrays you halfway through the game, so you end up seeing both of his personalities, even though he never ceases to be a moron and never ceases his stand-up-like jokes, which in my opinion makes him quite interesting, funny and enjoyable.  MULTIPLAYER The multiplayer coop campaign is a great experience that adds to the replay value of this game. It's just as good as the main campaign, except that it requires two thinking brains and Portal guns. It even brighten up a little bit this game's story, so it's pretty interesting, and it's quite long too.  Overall, this game is a masterpiece. If you do not own it yet, i truly recommend it.   BTW: Someone please teach Mr. Gabe Newell and the Valve team how to count to 3. They might be lacking some basic math here and pretty much the entire community would like a third installment to most of their games, such as Portal, Half-life and Left4Dead. Let's make number 3 a reality.

Portal 2 is the sequel to the fantastic puzzle game: Portal. Portal 2 take place many years after the original Portal. The aperture facility is almost completely overgrown with vines and weeds and after a malfunction in the machinery, Chell must find a way out of the dangerous area.   Portal 2, in my opinion, is better than portal in almost every way. You are shown another side of the Aperture testing facility and introduced to new mechanics. The story of this game is very interesting as well. If you enjoyed Portal, I would strongly recommend buying this game.   9/10

Portal 2 Is definantly my all-time favourite game. The story driven puzzle experience is just amazing! It is so satisfying when you solve a test in this game, and the detail and effects of each level are always beutiful! The differant characters and puzzle mechanics are also fantastic! Co-Op (Multiplayer) Just adds that amazing touch to this game, it is fun playing with friends!  Amazing Features of Portal 2: - Satisfying Puzzles - Deep Story - Level design & Asthetics - Playing with a friend (Co-Op) - Awesome soundtrack & Voice   EVERYTHING IS AMAZING!    10/10    Puzzlemaker and Hammer  The in-game puzzle maker is simple and minimalistic. It is good if you have a puzzle idea and just want to get it out. On the other hand, Hammer is way more advanced, but you can do almost anything you want in your puzzles! I personally recomend Hammer for puzzle-making. But if you are a begginer to level-design, start with puzzlemaker and build up to hammer.  Hope my review is helpful! :)

I have no words. I picked up this game at the summer sale and to be honest i can't say i had very high expectations. The first one were good but often the second game turns out worse, which doesn't seem to be happening at Valve. This is a great game! Really loved it! Right now i have already played the game twice and. The reason i decided to replay this fantastic game is probably not because of the 'game' itself, even tough the gameplay certainly had replayability, but the one reason i decided to do another playthrough is the voiceacting, especially Wheatley's. Stephen Merchant did such a good job as the sidekick for the player and everybody grew to love him. I never get tired of hearing his jokes during the game I would easily give it a 10/10  pros: Great game overall. Great story( Yes puzzle games can have good stories too). Great level design. Great puzzle's (obviously) And last but but least, great voice acting that made this game into a 'one in a lifetime' experience.  cons: i can litteraly only come up with ONE thing about the game that wasn't perfect, and the 'problem' were in the level design. In some parts of the game, like chapter 6-9 if i remember correctly. the levels were really open, that's all i'm gonna say to keep it spoiler free. (if you played the game you know what i mean). The 'problem' there, maybe it was just me but sometimes i found it really hard to know where you were supposed to go. My first playthrough i spent like 30 minutes trying to get a door open only to relaise that the door were a part of a puzzle i had already completed. Similar things happened more than a few times to me but i wouldn't call it a 'problem'. Overall it was a great game and it is totally worth every single euro (even tough i picked it up on sale). Still waiting for Portal 3 and Half-life 3 tough :I

Well well well. Portal 2. For those of you who have already seen my Portal review, you know what I think about the Portal franchise. Portal is a great game, with some frustrating parts. Portal 2 follows that same level of difficulty, but change GREAT, to AMAZING. First of all, our villain(s) are great. The voice acting is great once again, as are the characters. True, it is just the cores, Glados, Wheatly, and Cave Johnson and Carolin, but all of them with the exception of Carolin which I'll get to later are all geat. The game follows the same rutine that you did last time. Except the game visually looks MUCH BETTER. You can see this in the ruins of the old testing chambers and the ending cut scene. Now do you remember in the last game where you run from Glados, only to reach Glados? Well, in this game you do the same thing, until you reach Glados, who reawakens at the beginning of the game. You see, you've been traveling with Wheatly this whole time. A lovable robot with a great voice and personality. You then get to Glados, and replace her from full control to Wheatly. At the time, you think it's a great idea, until Wheatly does his laugh. He then promptly throws you and Glados out of the facility, giving you 18+ more stages to play! And while Glados scolds you for being stupid, you feel like it's your fault, and it is! But now the game is flipped. Wheatly and Glados have swapped, and she has become, A POTATO BATTERY. Well then. You then go through all these levels, where new mechanics are introduced. And durring these levels, you not only find out more about Apature curtesy of Cave Johnson's voice, you also find out that Glados is Carolin! You then finally make it back to Wheatly, and then have to endure a similar fight to the last game! BUT IN REVERSE. See with last time, you had to knock cores off of a defenseless Glados with rockets, slowly currupting herself, making her explode. Now here, you want to put cores onto Wheatly. Now you may actually want to listen to these cores for once, as they are hilarious. Namely Space Core. Now here, you do the same thing, but Wheatly defends himself! Anyway, the game 'ends' with Wheatly being sent to the moon, Glados being back in control, and Chel being sent away out of Apature. Now with online mode, or Co-op, you go through hard levels. Now, your experience is best with friends or having a mic, because believe me, people do troll here. And lastly, the level creator. I'm a fan of this in concept, but my computer just doesn't agree with the controls. If you can get more out of this mode, well more power to you. Overall, I think that Portal 2 is an amazing game.

Played this on PC and Steam Controller/ television and it was AMAZING, took us a few minutes to get the harder puzzles but the game overall is on point. Having the two robots makes it easier to do more complex jumps with team work. Along with unlimited custom mods for tons of fun in the Steam Workshop. Overall Rating 10/10 as it gave the users what we wanted and even more. More sequels to games shows that they pay attention to the fan base.

This game is absolutely a must-play for all puzzle game lovers. To sum up the likes about this game are it has    + Interesting storyline    + Good comical value    + Not too complex puzzles    + Opportunity to co-op with friends or other players    + New features: Propulsion gel and repulsion gel    + Expanse environment and involves new environment    + A sweet company after chapter 7 onwards    + Test chambers created by the community to try out    + Good ending    + Memorable song   I do not really have any dislike about this game except that I felt that the ending was easier than the previous Portal game. Overall, this game differs with any other puzzle games because of its rich storyline. Without it, Portal series would just be another ordinary game. Hopefully the developer can create Portal 3 in the future because they are many questions left unanswered.

Scroll back up and buy it already! This is Portal, the series that Yahtzee Croshaw, the Gordon Ramsey of gaming, called 'absolutely sublime from start to finish.' If that doesn't convince you to buy, I don't know what will.   But seriously, there are a few minor problems... Number one: the loading screens. They're much longer than they were in the first Portal, and a thirty-second respawn time is extremely frustrating in a game where you have to rely on trial and error. And the puzzles can be frustratingly hard, but hey, that's how puzzle games are supposed to be.  But other than that, Portal 2 is great. Gameplay? Equal parts thrilling and cerebral. Comedy? You'll chuckle more than Santa Claus playing Cards Against Humanity. An irresistably catchy pop tune? You got it. A solo opera performance by the actress who plays Glados? Oh, you didn't want one of those? Well, you're getting one, and you'll love it. Just like the rest of this game. You'll love it.

Okay, so, first review... (this probably isn't going to be very good...) Okay. So, Portal, Portal is a great classic game. I grew up with this game and I was in love with it the first time I saw its crystal clear graphics and heard its lovely character voicing... this game is awesome. Great graphics, great audio, great storyline, great mechanics, great test chamber creater, great merch, great community, great music, everything about this game is awesome. I cannot stress how worthy of twenty bucks this game is, and with the new sale it's only four dollars. Try Portal or Portal 2 out. For four bucks you have nothing to lose! So do yourself a favor and play this game.  There are only about two bad things in this game. 1: The puzzles start to get slightly hard and you might rage... (like, a lot) and 2: sometimes the puzzles are a bit unclear with what you have to do exactly... but overall this is still a great game.  If you are looking for a first-person shooter that has tons of combat and circles around war, this is not the game for you. But if you are looking for a funny, quirky, unique, and interesting puzzle game then this is definitely for you. 9/10 stars!

Prep 30 m Cook 1 h Ready In 7 h 30 m Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9 inch springform pan.  In a medium bowl, mix graham cracker crumbs with melted butter. Press onto bottom of springform pan.  In a large bowl, mix cream cheese with sugar until smooth. Blend in milk, and then mix in the eggs one at a time, mixing just enough to incorporate. Mix in sour cream, vanilla and flour until smooth. Pour filling into prepared crust.  Bake in preheated oven for 1 hour. Turn the oven off, and let cake cool in oven with the door closed for 5 to 6 hours; this prevents cracking. Chill in refrigerator until serving. SUMMARY After a short Portal this game comes with pretty much the same gameplay and main 'cool stuff'. However it logicaly continues in the good story, it adds new types of puzzles and runs smooth with not so bad graphics even after years. A good sequel, definitely worth playing after the 1st Portal.  89/100  PROS - even with just few characters the game is able to build a graduating story - the game gradually adds new types og puzzles so it doesn't stop being fun to play by the time - graphics look just fine, has low HW needs - after story mode there is a good coop mod  CONS - some locations could look nicer or more detailed - the game could give more information about its story and world lore

I'll admit, I'm not one to write positive reviews. It is far easier to rant about something you hate rather than give out glowing praise. The other reason it that I'm not too great at it. However, I abandoned all those foolish notions and am currently tapping my review to the rhythmic sounds of 'Want you gone', humming quietly to myself in my basement, with all the lights off save my computer, in my Wheatley Laboratories hoodie, a turret at my left and my mousepad at my right, not having slept for a longer time than I would care to admit, nearly done with playthrough god-knows-what, five and a half years after this game's release while I listen to the sounds of people telling me Portal is dead slowly fade into the background as I turn up my music. I literally cannot give a higher recommendation. This is my favorite game of all time.  The sheer fact that a main story as short as Portal 2's could manage to give me not only so much playtime, but also the willingness to spend 4 times the game's cost worth of money on merchandise, It really shows just how amazing a game can be. I'm not one to spend money on a whim, either. But this is all besides the point.   The story is very short, and if there is a drawback, and it has some pacing issues once you know what to do in all the puzzles (that's hardly fair though). I haven't even looked into speedrunning techniques but I can finish the normally 8-12 hour campaign in around two hours simply taking the most direct routes and knowing exactly where to go and what to do when you get there. However while the story itself it relatively short, believe me, it makes up for it in sheer quality. It doesn't have any moving political commentary or complex morals (or any at all, really) and the plot at it's base definitely isn't anything new, but if you're looking at buying this game and somehow have not heard about the beautifully clever and witty dialogue gracing the three or four characters, oh man, you are in for a treat. The best of them by far is Wheatley, with practically every line he says being something you can laugh at (I have an entire folder with about 30 pages of drawings of just him saying some of his more quoteable lines), but every character has their time to shine. GLaDOS has a lot of good stuff in the latter half of the game and I've straight up seen Cave Johnson's 'Do you know who I am?! I'm the man whose gonna BURN YOUR HOUSE DOWN! With the LEMONS!' on t-shirts. The writers over at Valve are a seriously gifted bunch, I must say. Portal's dialogue was great, but it does not in any way compare to it's younger brother. Portal 2's plot is actually surprisingly dark once you begin looking deeper into it, especially if you've played the game as much as I have. Spoilers ahead obviously, but you watch Cave Johnson go from a slightly reckless happy scientist to slowly losing finantial support from the government, losing test subjects and employees and finally poisoning himself accidentally with moon rocks, where you hear his dying wishes to put Caroline in charge (who is actually part of GLaDOS now) followed by a 'Good-bye, sir.' from the Caroline in GLaDOS that honestly gets me everytime. Looking into more of Aperture's backstory and revealing how nearly everyone was killed by a rogue GlaDOS, aside from one man who is half going insane and ended up being the one that saved Chell from the fate that claimed all of the other 10-15,000 test subjects holed up in Aperture's relaxation center at the cost of his own life and it ends up weaving this fantastic story where the darkness of what really happened to these characters is hidden within lighthearted and hilarious dialogue that makes the darkness interesting, but never overwhelming. Anything potentially ominious goes with something you can laugh at (see anytime anyone makes a death threat, ESPECIALLY Wheatley) so you never feel weighed down by some of the gravity of the deeper story. I honestly cannot praise it enough. It is something to behold.  Gameplay wise I can't say anything that won't be repeating someone else, but puzzles are highly inventive, never too convoluted or frusterating and all enjoyable and even on your first go, and figuring the game out is very satisfying, even if the level isn't too terribly hard. It has become the game I play to relax, and I love it like a son because of that. The only real issue is far too many of the puzzles are dependent on falling somewhere to launch yourself somewhere else, but to be fair that is a pretty efficient way of getting places sooo... I don't know. I will say though while that is prevelant, it is used in plenty of different ways, so it feels fresh each time it appears.  This was honestly the best 20 bucks I've ever spent, even if it was far, far after the hype had gone. I'd like to say, if the fact this is an older game discourages you from buying, don't let it. I have gotten far more enjoyment out of this than most things I've had in my life, and despite the fact I jumped on a bandwagon that had been abandoned at the side of the road long ago, I don't regret a thing. The dialogue still makes me laugh and the characters are seriously top notch, and I haven't tired of it this far through. That has to be a mark of quality of some sort.

Valve takes another successful step forward with Portal 2, a worthy sequel in every aspect.  The game manages to keep everything which worked fine in the first Portal while adding content, lore and improving the gameplay. The game's mechanics are smooth and responsive, and the escalating puzzles' difficulty poses always a balanced challenge.  The storytelling is brilliant thanks to its smart humor and the plot is captivating because of its uniqueness and unpredicatability. All this is sustained by unforgettable characters, perfectly portrayed.  As far as the visual aspect, Portal 2 has the same, appealing minimalistic aesthetic of its predecessor, which fits the lore and helps the player to focus on resolving the puzzles without driving away his attention. The soundtrack as well is immersive without being invasive.  The solo campaign isn't very long, but the game features a co-op mode (with a real, interesting plot behind it) which adds a lot of longevity, especially thanks to the thousands of maps which are freely downloadable from the community's workshop.  Nobody should miss this milestone of the gaming history, a game which keeps aging very well.

Phenomenal game. I played the first Portal years ago quite eagerly, enjoyed it thoroughly. When I found out that one of my all-time favorite games was getting a sequel, I was stoked. And boy, did this game blow me away. Significantly longer than the first game, with a much more in-depth story and a couple more incredible characters, Portal 2 was exceptional. Don't know why I took so long to review it, but here I am. The co-op mode is incredibly fun, obviously the story isn't as invested as the single player mode.  It's a bit frustrating if you're trying to play with someone that isn't particularly co-operative, which is counterintuitive, I know. But the gestures help if you're playing without a mic. I love the options to create maps, though I haven't made many myself, all the ones on my account were made by my brother. Amazing game, amazing story, great graphics, enjoyable music. All in all, I'd definitely give this game a 10/10, looking forward to playing through it again sometime soon.

Portal 2 is one of the best games I have ever played. Not that there is only an awesome story but the gameplay is just beatiful and nothing else! The graphics? It has one of the best graphics I have ever seen. Another +, I have not experienced a SINGLE bug for the time me playing! And I have completed this game a couple of times.  The puzzles, oh the puzzles...they're difficult at times but not so difficult that they're boring! This is proven by the fact that the 11 year old me enjoyed playing this game until the end. Some puzzle games have overly easy, repetetive and boring puzzles or puzzles that are just university level of physics and math. You have none of that here! Entertaining, unique, and not overly complicated. That is if you don't go into the community levels...  Talking about community made levels...it was a brilliant idea to introduce the level making in game! And the level maker is easy to understand aswell! You just need a little bit of imagination and a brain to make a level! And if you're skilled, you can literally make a horror game inside a puzzle game! Yes there are levels that are horror levels. That is how much you can mess around with this game, as long as you have the brain for that.  And the price? The price, for such an awesome game, is like giving god a piece of dirt to bring back Jesus and he does it.   So yes, I do think this game is not only worth your money but they're also worth your time.

The one concern I had about buying this game was that the main campaign is very short (10-15 hours). But the online community is very active and there are thousands upon thousands of user-submitted puzzles that keep the game fresh and fun. As long as you have the itch to play the game there's always something new to do. The campaign alone is a blast and a must-play; all the online content on top of that more than makes this a worthwhile purchase. Just buy it; it's great.
The best game!

Much like the original Portal, this game is a showcase for brilliant puzzles and interesting concepts. Nevertheless, this game truly outshines its predecessor through a unique story, quirky characters, an unusual yet unobtrusive soundtrack, and a starkly beautiful setting, all of which is at least as engaging as the gameplay. While some avid puzzle fans might prefer the purity and simplicity of the original Portal (which I highly recommend playing first if you haven't already), I believe that Portal 2 is the game that Portal always should have been.

Im reviewing only the single player campaign since its the main part of the game:  The story is really, i mean REALLY ingenious. knowing just a little bit of story from the first portal game makes this game even better.  While the first test chambers are easy to medium, the rest of the game isn't hard, but will sure make you search for the walkthrough on youtube.  The game can be finished legit in 3 hours, but most people do it in ~6 hours, if you dont hunt for easter eggs and references on how Apereture Science violated OSHA countless times.  In my opinion, this game is worth 100% buying, it has a great lore, even better soundtrack and very cool mechanics.
